Entry.4: Batt arrived 2 a.m. very dirty and ragged, met Anderson & Irvine Cullen and Major Ralston.
Entry.5:
From 8 – 24 did training generally on historic battle field of Tel-El-Kelin. While here had some very pleasant rides with the Padre Father Clune & Sadler the signalling officer. Nearly every Wednesday & Saturday afternoon rode across desert to village 5 mls away. The village always had its market day on Wednesday, have photographs of it.

Left Tel-El-Kelin for Canal Zone arrived Ferry Post 4 p.m.
Entry.6: Stayed at Ferry post all day, cold & windy.
Entry.7: left at 9 a.m. for Hill 353, Australia Hill, rained all day very heavy going over sand. arrived at 19th Batt. position 5 p.m.
Entry.9: Outpost at night, rained heavily bitterly cold.
Entry.10: Spent in roaming round, weather beautiful, large number of large black beetles, also some death adders & several kinds of animal, a dog and a small dear, very hard to see & very shy.
Entry.11: Church parade went for walk with Padre, did 10 mls across desert.
Entry.13: Spent in digging trenches & outpost at night.
Entry.14: Left Hill 383 for m.gun school at Zeitoun 9.30 a.m. rained night.
Entry.15: arrived Zeitoun 2 a.m. went to zoo in afternoon took photos.
Entry.18: went to Mrs. Williamson Naasti with Alan Smith for dinner.
Entry.19: Visited 5 Training Batt. went to Church Cairo at night
Entry.23: Spent in town, church at night.
Entry.24:
– 24

Routine, met Mrs. Buchannan in Cairo, staying with daughter at Rossmore House. Charch-el-Mandcheck, can get good English meal here.
Entry.26: Left Zeitoun for Batt. 11.30 a.m. arrived Ishmalia 6.30 p.m. Ferry Post 10.30 stayed night at staging camp.
Entry.29: Trench digging, heavy sand storm on
Entry.31: Trench work ended, fired musketry Orderly officer felt very sick.
Entry.32: Exchanged mk 111 for mk 1V1 getting appetite back, ready to move.
Entry.33:
received orders to move 10 a.m. Monday had boxing tournay Gen. Holmes present also Holmes & Travers 
to did
 dinner.
Entry.34:
Left hill 353 11.00 a.m. arrived staging camp 3 p.m. put up tents

4

relieved by N.Z. M.R.
Entry.35: Reveille 5.30 a.m. cross canal (took photo) arrived Yrascan 12 mid, vy hot.
Entry.36: drill morning swim in canal afternoon much appreciated.
Entry.37: drill, kit inspection. Lecture on gas helmets, inoculated T.A.L.
Entry.38: duty coy censored letters all day.
Entry.39: drill morning cold with high S.E. wind blowing mis-laid trunk.
Entry.40: Church parade chappie & I had tea in Ishmalia.
Entry.42:
–

Drill in morning had swim in afternoon.
Entry.43:
–

musketry all day marking first sensation of bullet passing close overhead.
Entry.44: orders to move to France by H.M.T. Ascamia
Entry.45:
–

getting ready to move, entrained 12 mid-night.
Entry.46:
Left 
Ish
 Yrascan 2.30 a.m. arrived Alex 12.30 p.m.

5

boarded Ascania large well equipped boat.
Entry.47: Ascania moved out into stream 12.30 p.m. left Alex 4.30 p.m. Church service bland played as we left port.
Entry.48: blowing fair sea, feeling bit dopy. Batt. ord. officer. did 161 mls.
Entry.49: weather beautiful passed 16 trawlers & 1 destroyer up to 12 m. day did 275 miles average 11.3 pursued zig zag course.
Entry.50:
did 282 mls average 11.6 knots weather fine sports on board, had concert every night.

23//3/16

fine, saw Malta did 213 knots, stayed in Malta Harbor 2 hrs.
Entry.51: Sports did 293 knots passed Sardinia 12 mid day.
Entry.52:
Sighted France. Mts. look snow capped but not so. Saw Prison of Monte Christo. Temp 55 ° F. arrived 5.30 at entrance to Harbour, enormous cliffs of white stone rise straight out of water. Harbour in large artificial break water

6
Entry.53: sighted France early in morning. docked at Marseille 5.30 p.m. great excitement on a P&O branch liner. stayed in dock all night. officer on guard.
Entry.54:
Disembarked after dinner and went for route march through Marseilles. Wonderful reception 1st Colonial troops to march through city. Could not march properly owing to crowd. returned to boat had tea on wharf. Ascania drew away back to Alex. left wharf at 7.00 p.m. marched to railway. entrained at 9.30 p.m.

7
Entry.55: First town to see was Orange at daybreak. very similar to Orange in N.S.W. in climate & appearance. very cold. supplied with tea. That day passed through Orange 4.30 am, Montilimon, Vienne, Lyon 12.00 had meals. Macon Dijon 9.30 gave away practically everything as souvenirs. You gave away anything from clips of cartridges to iron rations. The whole journey the train 50 carriages long was a mass of waving arms, flags & blankets.
Entry.56:
Sens 7.0 a.m. Montereau breakfast at 10 a.m. from Melun onwards followed left bank of seine locks all way boats pulled along by chains in middle of river. Country all cultivated & grape vines. Arrived Junisy 5 miles outside Paris at 1.30, turned west

8

through Versailles, St. Germain, Beaumont, Clermont & St. Pol. had tea at Epluches from here followed canal until dark. passed Longerean & through Amiens about midnight.

29/3/16

Disentrained
 detrained at Bergette at 8.30 had breakfast. moved out along road no signs of war. issued with another blanket new. On way to billets passed through Thiennes, steinbeck, billetted at Boesighem. I am with my platoon in La Brasserie. Have room containing bed, washstand & cupboard. very comfortable. 1st night extremely cold. small amount of snow fell about 2.30 p.m. building of most importance is the church.
Entry.58: Hear guns bombarding towards La Bassee. guns fire continuously day & night. Big 15" about 2½ mls away shakes house when it fires. firing line 15 mls away.
Entry.59: Weather continues fie & warm. In morning went to gas demonstration use xylene Br. in shells. affect gunners eyes unable to see not injurious has sweet smell not unlike m. acetate. Put on helmets passed through trench filled with Scl4. helmets absolutely efficient 1st wearing of helmet gives a sensation of suffocation. necessary wear helmet before going into business. 6th Bge was reviewed by Kitchener.
Entry.60: Morning parade, played cricket in afternoon.
Entry.61:
Beautiful day, cricket and read in sun.

10
Entry.62: Morning off. Piquet Officer in Aire in afternoon. Sent telegram home roamed round streets. children have already got the idea that the Australian has plenty of money “un sous".
Entry.63: Went to demonstration of so called liquid fire. jet of oil forced out through a nozzle under pressure of 120 atmos. of N. oil used parraffin, petrol & lubric oil. moral effect only when troops under cover.
Entry.64:
Left Breseghem at 7.00 a.m. marched with Lt. Donaldson to B.H.Q. Steinbecque took motor bus to Oxelaire via Mosbecque, Hayebrouche St. Marie Cappel & Cassel. Lecture on gas at Oxelaire practical use of gas. used goggles as protection against xylyl Bromide helmet (for cylinder of El & Cocl2) cloud thick enough

12

to obscure objects at 2 yds. no entrance of gas into helmet. (gas proof dugouts 2 doors 1 yd apart – blanket wet). Arrived Breseghem 8.00 p.m. fine view from Cassel.
Entry.65: Gave lecture to Coy. on gas in morning received orders to move. taking gramaphone.
Entry.66:
Reviewed by Joffre at Mosbecque

Reveille 5.30 a.m. moved off at 8.15. arrived Oulternsteen 4.30 p.m. via Hayebrouch, Borre, Pradelles, strayecle & Merris sound of guns much closer. billetted in houses did 15 mls.
Entry.67: Left Oultersteen 10.30 passed through le Verrien, steinwerck and Hallobean billetted in Jesus farm on bank of canal La Lys. Saw first aeroplane shot at with shrapnel. Germans shot 4 planes about 2000 ft high no result fired about 50 shot in each case did 10 mils. weather cold. Lt Blumer reported missing.
Entry.68:
Rest all day, plane shot at overhead pieces of shell 

12

9/4/16

fell close by. country covered with water, cold north wind blowing. 3 mls off firing line hear guns & rifles plainly shooting again started toward ypres. 1500.
Entry.69: Some fine shooting by Germans at our aeroplane. Saw tanks. left jesus fm 8.00 p.m. arrived billets on Rd outside L’Armie 11 o’clock. Farm considerably knocked about with shrapnel billetted at H.18.C. streaky bacon farm.
Entry.70:
Several shrapnel fell near this morning. Kitchen roof full of shrapnel holes. Farm houses nearby in ruins. Front quiet 2000 yds off firing line. effect of shrapnel overrated. In afternoon went out to find the emergency roads for use in an alarm. Entrance to our front line by means of Shaftesbury Avenue. shell holes all over ground. Village of Bois Grenier in ruins.

13
Entry.71: weather rainy & cold. stayed in billet
Entry.73: North of France no place for Australians. Visited trenches in the morning. trenches built up owing to water floor of duck boards. communications trench about 1 ml long. at 7.45 reported at greatwood avenue to South of Shaftesbury Av. to carry R.E. stores. Fatigue party of 80 men worked men to a finish by 1.30 a.m. German bullets go off like explosive bullets when they burst near you. nickel casing too thin, does away with a lot of strays (wrong h.b.t) {crack when pass you}
Entry.74:
another cold day. rainy. orders to go into trenches to-night. orders cancelled going into to-morrow night.

15/4/16

weather fine. visited trenches in morning. Left billets

14
Entry.75: at 8.00 p.m. and relieved 17th Batt by 10.0 p.m. without a hitch. enemy quiet all night. did watch 1. – 5.00 in night.
Entry.76:
rained all day. trenches about 1 ft deep in mud. use duckboards in all trenches 
on watch 5.0 12
 . snipers only men shooting. German sniper an excellent shot gets top of sandbag every shot. night Germans use great quantity of Very lights.
Entry.77:
weather fine in morning rained at night on duty 12 – 2a.m. 4 – 12 midday and put in 2 loop holes.

19/4/16

rainy again. nothing can be seen of the germans except a few working parties well in the rear. yesterday our artillery fired 20 rounds and blew up a few german billets. a trench mortar is installed near my dug-out.

16

Enemy trench 300 – 400 yds away. Have not as yet been shelled. Rifle bullets take no notice of. as yet no casualties. Shells frequently pass overhead shelling places in rear. cause a whistling noise. The only way to have a decent time in the trenches is to be a fatalist. German aeroplanes fly very high 12000 ft. ours much lower 2000 ft. One of ours nearly came to grief, flew to low & was shot at with m. gun rifle & shrap. volplaned at a terrific rate & escaped. probably reported by germans as a hit.

still raining everything soaked through. trench motor 2" fired 2 bombs 60 lbs 12.00 at 12.30 while at dinner German batteries replied with H.E. fired 44 shells in 10"

17

first experience of shell fire for first six shots god down low behind parapet and hoped shell did not lob in top of me. could feel the draw as they passed. after first six got hold of myself and went down line to see how my fellows were taking it. by time last had gone over had my pipe alight and was talking to cook at cookhouse. the men I brought over took it extremely well. a couple hit parapet but luckily the majority were high & skimmed over parapet to lob about 20 to 100 yds away. Germans repeated dose 35 at 4.45 nobody hit. In B Company got altogether 4 men

18
Entry.78: cont. returned to billet at 11.0 p.m.
Entry.79: weather fine. took fatigue party to trenches from 4 a.m. to 2 p.m. went thoroughly over all trenches in our sector. phonograph broken.
Entry.80: Still raining. cleared a little in afternoon. went to Enquinham to look for dentist no success.
Entry.81:
Rained heavy all day duck boards in some places 1ft under water. took working party to trenches. working up to knees in mud. returned early.

23/4/16

Fine day. men took opportunity to get things dry. returned to trenches at 8 p.m. my platoon in support. Lt. Olive 5th engineers killed by shell. shell landed on his shoulder.

19

24/4/16 

Fine and warm morning quiet. Artillery duel in Afternoon our guns fired more than Germans. Just at sunset German shell hit church tower in Bois Grenier. Tower fell to ground amid huge cloud of red dust. 7 Bdge at 9.00 p.m. used trench mortar. 
20th patrol captured
Entry.82:
Another beautiful day. Artillery duel in afternoon. C Coy 17th shelled (billet) 
E7
 4 casualties one killed. German gun about 10" howitzer. billet set on fire. hear ammunition exploding.
Entry.83: Fine and warm. our artillery bombarded enemies front line trenches from 11.30 to 12 noon, firing approx. 150 shells. H.E. & shrapnel. enemy replied from 12.35 to 1.15 p.m. firing mostly H.E. 5.9". in 1st 10 minutes fired 124 shells fired in all about 450 shells. B. Coy no casualties C. Coy 3 fired on front line & supports. carried away bridge & smashed up commun. trench. German attack on Ypres salient no success. Gas & shells used.
Entry.84: Found out afterwards that gas was used & enemy attacked our casualties very heavy attack was round Ypres.
Entry.85: Fine and warm. drained commun. Trenches. Relieved by “C" Coy
Entry.86:
left trench 8.30 p.m. cleared shaftesbury Av. and emergency rd. when gas alarm given. a battery on right opened fire immediately with 5" batteries all around were shooting 
hard
 all they knew. Shooting continued for 30 minutes air one mass of humming shells. Germans replied on our front line. no gas came.
Entry.87: Drew pay at Crois du Bac. day fine. couple of shells landed near billet otherwise all quiet.
Entry.89:
Beginning at dawn 2.30 am from 1230 to 2.00 a.m. heavy firing from Plug St north of Armentiers proved to be a gas attack. Germans reported to be mobilizing around this Salient. weather fine and warm. Trenches rapidly drying up. Made applic. for Bge. job. requiring knowledge of new guns & motor cars & cycles.

21
Entry.90: At 5.0 p.m. Germans scorched a field about 300 yds away from our billet for a battery fired about 150 shells 8.2" no luck.
Entry.92:
Field A.M.C. to get tooth fixed attended to by Lieut. Sutton. Knows George. Chappie leaves for England on Friday on leave. 8 days from Boulongne to Boulougne. Got word of Townshend’s Surrender makes outlook darker. Have Russian troops near Ypres. A push on this front will be made soon. If this push is held up it means that we shall have to act on defensive until things are properly organised to accept terms of peace. The former will take years and the latter unthinkable. The Germans in front of us are well fed & clothed and there is no semblance of ammunition shortage.

22
Entry.93:
Fine. left billet 7.0 a.m. relieved 17th in reserve. rest {day do fatigues at night} artillery fairly quiet bombardment on night of gas alarm quietened Germans considerably. Reported bring up more guns & men. trenches dry and well built. my dugout surrounded by trees just coming out in leaf. creek runs round 2 sides. very pretty.

3/5/16

Fine. quiet all day. Heavy firing all night towards La Bassee.
Entry.94:
Fine. Few shells sprinkled on working parties. otherwise quiet. Took out working party at night. no casualties.

5/5/16

Fine. Had good wash and general clean up. At 3.30 p.m. roving gun opened fire just behind trench. German 1st reply fell within 100 yds of guns. answered each other for about 6 shots then gun imshied. Germans then shortened and fired on trenches got too warm so ordered platoon out of trench. just got them clear when knocked in 2 dugouts and parapet in 2 places. in last salvo they fired 4 shrap.

23
Entry.95: and 2 H.C. one shell cut trce in half. At 8.0 p.m. they opened with shrapnel on front trenches & supports. bombardment last 1½ hours. stand to ordered and all supports were brought up. Ammun. served out thought it was finish. however it subsided. found out that German raiding party had attacked under shrap. fire. & entered 20th Batt. trench. 20 casualties 20 killed 80 wounded at 6 a.m. on
Entry.96:
Still digging for the buried. our artillery replied damaged done not yet know. Gas alarm. shells gradually get on nerves. 

6/8/16

Bombarded my sector again this morning using 8.2 H.E. very jumpy. had sleep after dinner felt much better. night very quiet.
Entry.97: Fine quiet all day. repaired damage done previous day. the only way to get peace of mind is to be a fatalist.
Entry.98:
cold snap set in. rained a little during day. heavy fatigues during day night. Carrying wire to front line front line coys put out 100 coils at night.

24
Entry.99: Light rain all day. few shells fired. this morning one man narrow escape – Keirde – sitting on seat in front of dug out shell pieced parapet 2 ft away, tore his equipment & clothing to pieces. suffered from slight shock only. My present dug-out is 18’ x6" x6". very comfortable. have good brazier going to keep things warmed. New bombardment on 20th Batt. Germans reported to have used 10,000 shells. Some 10" shells used. Splinted 24" long picked up. makes hole 30’ x 4’ German raiding party on same night captured 5 men. 2 m. guns & 2 stoke mortars. No Germans capt.
Entry.100:
Fine cold wind. Bombarded again during day received 47 5.9 shells, breached parapet in 2 places. destroyed 3 dug-out. 1 man injured, several narrow escapes. One landed 10 yds from me thought it was finish. seems to be very little side burst. destroyed house 100 yds in our rear. night quiet. Batt lost 10, 2 killed.

25
Entry.101:
Fine. Germans shooting our support line. 10.30 am. One of our aeroplanes brought down by german m.gun fire. fell between our 2nd &3rd lines. 
damage repaired & plane rose 1 hr later.
Entry.102: Relieved by D coy. 17th Batt & arrived billets 10.00 a.m. met Diamond in Bois Grenier belongs to 5th F.A. looked from Ast. observation Post.
Entry.103: Raining. On fatigue to-night carrier engineers stores from 9.15 pm to 2.30 am. men beginning to feel the strain of incessant fatigue. The aeroplane which fell on 11/5/16 Pilot shot of m. gun plan fell like stone until 200 ft of ground when observer took command of machine & managed to effect a landing. got clear of machine when it was destroyed by german shell fire. wonderful exhibition of pluck and resource.
Entry.104:
Cold and cloudy. Communion service in morning & service at 7 p.m. did some trick cycling on bicycles round courtyard

26
Entry.105: Wet all day had working party this morning. wrote to Joy, Johnson this afternoon. Feeling very dopy. shooting on left all day.
Entry.106: Fine, quiet all day. Rode into Armentiers. German battery opened fire on one of our batteries fired 200 shells, burnt barn but Australians rescued the gun lost ammunition.
Entry.107: Another beautiful day. Visited Armentiers again. Town very quiet. Went on fatigue at night 8.220 pm – 12.30 am. 3 gas alarms.
Entry.108: Fine again. Summer weather. plenty of aeroplanes up. supplied information re my appointment to A.I.F. etc.
Entry.109:
Quiet all day. warm light cool breeze. Germans fired on our 8" battery got one gun blew track off. 
Telegram home
Entry.110: Fine very little shooting at night took working party to trenches.
Entry.111:
Quiet all day. Heavy shooting at evening towards La Bassee at mid-night message came through to be ready to stand-to.

27
Entry.112: Received orders to go into trenches. At 5.00 p.m. received message for 2 working parties to dig new fire line in no-mans-land. Though this seemed an impossible task, the parties were got ready & Swallow and myself to take charge. We both knew that there was no chance of coming back. Horrible feeling to think you are going to be killed. just before starting order was changed for whole coy. to move out for same job. bit more comforting. Ultimately dug trench between Tramway Av. and Shaftesbury Av. A few strays flying about but nothing like what the other would have been. I was very glad to see the billet & have a good supper at 1.30 a.m.
Entry.113: No more orders received yet. Wether fine continued with relief. finished by 10.30 p.m. platoon occupied same position as when in firing line before.
Entry.114:
lot of work to be done in trenches. mens programme 
work from sleep
 on watch 12.30 a.m to

28

2.30 am. Sleep till 8.30 am. work on trench 8.30 – 12.00 mid-day. rest in afternoon till 8.00 pm except sentries. work again till 12.30 am. in the 24 hrs I do a watches of 8.5 hrs. superintend work in trench and do wiring in no-mans-land from 9.0 pm. – 12.00 mid. shooting done by our batteries only.
Entry.115: our batteries fired on & off all day on enemy parapet. Germans replied with a few shrap. got one man with piece of shell case. 1st man had actually seen shot hit in head through steel helmet. Our artillery seems to be livening up. fired on German parapet as early as 3.0 a.m.
Entry.116: Heavy bombardment on Birdeaux salient by our artillery at 3.0 am. fired 400 rounds all sizes aided by bombs from our front line. great sight from our first Trench. Germans replied not very heavily from 1 pm – 4.30 am. They shelled our front line with
Entry.117: one battery of 77 mm. wounding 3 slightly. at 5.0 pm we shelled brewery & to left. our batteries fired more to-day than have done since we took over line.
Entry.118:
Germans bombarded our side of Birdeaux Salient at 6.0 a.m. we replied desultory shooting on both sides during day. at 8.0 p.m one of our aeroplanes few towards up from their lines. just getting dark & could see flash of shrapnel & it burst. must have fired about 1000 shot. wonderful how aeroplane escaped whole batteries firing together shell bursting all round it.

28//5/16

Germans fired 50 77’s along our front. 3 casualties A coy. another fine exhibition of flying by one of our planes, flew right across German lines under heavy fire to get a heavy battery that was firing circled round battery & returned unharmed.
Entry.119:
Our batteries shooting all day. German replies at intervals with 

30

29/5/16

with heavy shells. shelled our billet at 12.0 midday, damage not yet known. Casualties mounting up. A company lost 7, 5 killed this morning. German shells giving out a large cloud which looks like suplhur. night quiet rained all night. Billet badly damaged lost nothing.
Entry.120:
Dull all day. Trenches inspected by Gen. Birdwood. heavy firing on 
Armentiers
 Ypres salient at 8.0 pm. & on 1st division on right other side of Flemboix. Armentiers shelled & 
to be was
 could be seen to be on fire at night. Erguinhem shelled also.

31/5/16

Our batteries opened fire at 5 o’clock enemy replied he threw over big bombs on 18th batt. 5 casualties in 18th last week. German has been firing lot of 77 mm. shrapnel very quick. perfectly safe under parapet. very dangerous if caught in the open. The black 5.9 inch worst. burst with tremendous crash. make you feel very jumpy waiting for them is the worst. not so bad when shells actually bursting around you. Canadian N.C.O. came to us for experience in trench as officer.
Entry.122: Our artillery bombarded front line 5.0 p.m. Trench mortar fired at same time when Fritz fires his mortar we open with our 60 pounder result is that Fritz shuts up. 2 days ago he fired 2 bombs we fired 4 has not replied since. things are gradually coming to a climax when one side will have to give in to the other in regard to artillery superiority. Enemy artillery very active during afternoon heaving firing on both flanks all afternoon. At 6.30 pm observation baloon broke loose & floated over german lines. Also lost a plane & battery by sell fire.
Entry.124:
dinner at Ablassia in Town & country 29th March 1916. Work done by platoon during 10 days 32 hurdles 4 dugouts 700 sand bags & cut 50 yds of traffic trench. desultory artillery fire all day on both sides, heavy artillery fire at 9 pm & 5.0 pm on left reported german captured 300 yds of our trench. Canadian left 4.30 p.m. 

3/6/16

Quiet all day, weather fine, cold north wind blowing. report of naval

32

engagement off Jutland no details. relieved b y D Coy 17th Batt. arrived billets 11.30 pm had supper in bed by 1.30 am.
Entry.125: See by daylight damage done to billet – mens portion hardly touched whole roof of our part gone walls of both bedrooms blown completely down. dining room fortunately only slightly damaged used not as bedroom. has been very cold all day heavy artillery firing by us at 6.0 p.m. Church service held in barn.
Entry.126: Dull, cold N.E. wind took working party to trenches. visited Armentiers. 7th Bgd. raid supposed to take place whole division had orders to stand to shows clearly that who ever ordered stand to has no idea of proportion or that he is afraid of the Germans. Sat in support trench all night did no work. stood to till 2 a.m.
Entry.127:
Cold, dull. Dent arrived back from leave tells tales of reception that makes one homesick. 7th Bgd stunt came off. Sent telegram home via England. Artillery

33

started at 11.20 & bombarded in great style for 40 minutes fired about 5000 rounds mostly of 4.7" howitzer were destroyed by 2" mortar throwing 60 lb bombs. 80 men in raid entirely successful captured 6 prisoners, our total losses 4 killed 10 wounded. no mail for long time last letter dated April 2nd.
Entry.128: Quiet all day. German Fokker biplane overhead at 5.0 pm beautiful sunset. strawberries in back garden ripe. cherries nearly ripe. new wire cutters issued fit on bayonet.
Entry.129: weather cold and rainy. German artillery seems to be much quieter since raid. strawberries doing well bomb throwing practice.
Entry.130: fine with cold wind 7 of our planes overhead at 6.0 p.m. on fatigue at night, bombs from our 2" mortar exploded on gun pit no casualties. Fort Vaux taken by Germans. persistent rumours of peace.
Entry.131:
Beautiful day desultory artillery fire. detailed for bomb school.

34

Dent & Blumer went to Armentiers. got my coat & some photograph needles.
Entry.132: Dull rained in morning. heard caustic remarks passed about 3 a.m. when rain came through roof. lump of plaster hanging by piece of paper has not yet fallen. had dinner last night. visitors were Wallack, Forsyth, Weedon, Heath. menu: - sardines on Toast, roast pork, roast potatoes & peas. baked pudding with sauce & pineapple. Reported Batt. H.Q. 12.00 Bge Hg 1.0 p.m. bomb school at Boudrelle 4.o p.m. walked all way about 6 mls. passed through Erquinhem & Croix de Bas. Camped in hut with Douglas from D. Coy very comfortable. went for walk to Sailly. Busy little town billeting 1 division.
Entry.133:
Rained all day. had lecture in morning on grenades fuses and explosives. practice in bomb throwing in the afternoon got highest point in squad. Heavy artillery fire on left at 10 p.m.

35
Entry.134: Rained heavily all day. no work in afternoon went for a walk with Douglas to Stienwerk. heavy firing north of Armentiers all day & night. Russians captured Lemberg raid by 1st division & success. captured 2 m. guns & 1 trench mortar &6 prisoners. English grenades in this school one G.S. No. 1, Hale’s No. 2, No. 3 Hales rifle grenade. Newton rifle grenade. Mill’s bomb. No. 19 hand grenade & No. 20 rifle grenade modification of No. 3 explosive gun cotton T.N.T. aminol & Tonite. C.E. primer in No. 1 G.S. length of school probably increased 2 days owing to wet.
Entry.135:
Practice in throwing live grenades. Mill’s by hand & with west’s thrower reach up to 250 yds. also grenades No. 3 & & rainy. Chappie paid visit in afternoon.

36
Entry.136: Dull small amount of rain. practice in grenade throwing in morning. In afternoon had exam in grenade throwing easily came top. Met Chappie in Steenwerk at 6.30 p.m had tea in nice French House. Booth who played LaCrosse with Mosman went with me to Steenwerk. returned 9.30 pm. All clocks put on an hour last night at 9.0 p.m. in accordance with light saving scheme. 7th Bge. received orders to stand in readiness to move. They are taking over part of line South of St. Eloi, from Canadians.
Entry.137: Fine & cloudy. Cold N.E. wind more practice in bomb throwing. Roydhouse one of officers from
Entry.138:
Bge 28th Batt. at Bomb School very similar to myself in ideas & ambitions. Undergrad of science in Perth Uni, finished 1 year. Knew Townshend & Auroussean. Wish he was in 19th Batt. return to Batt tomorrow.

37

There is undoubtedly going to be a push on a large scale here shortly. at 11.15 heavy artillery fire about followed by gas at 12.0 midnight though here we are 9000 yds behind firing lines had to put helmets on. helmets absolutely effective.

17/6/16

practice in grenade throwing & oral exam in morning after dinner lecture resumes on work done at school. Left for Boudrelle at 2.30 pm. had bath at Divisional bath. 5.0 p.m. arrived billet 10.55 pm. left for trenches 8.30 p.m. relief completed by 10.30 p.m. without incident.
Entry.139:
Quiet all day. Heavy artillery bombardment on 
both enemy
 enemy lines at both salients. 7th Bge. made stunt. Germans prepared not a success. Enemy weak in artillery opposite here same condition reported by canadians opposite their front. Russians still advancing. captured 12000 more prisoners total to date 172,000 

38
Entry.140: General Birdwood inspected trenches in morning. German guns seem to have been moved from our front. Our batteries have unlimited ammunition at least & have orders to return 2 for 1 doing it with good results.
Entry.141: German shells set on fire a Church in Armentieres, burnt to ground. Church was used as O.P. otherwise all quite.
Entry.142:
Men here all day from 14 & 16 Batts. to get into trench routine before taking over. our batteries very active. Germans got some of their Artillery back again. German batt 
O.B.9 or
 0.98 5.9 inch back.

22/6/16

Artillery in front of us strong again. Heavily bombarded the 18th A 6 Bge. attached to us for a few days. Our 2" trench mortar cut wire in front of us at 11 p. german retaliation

39

small. Heavy artillery on left reported used of gas. The gas used by Germans on
Entry.143: caused 500 casualties to Tommies owing to lack of instruction and defective helmets no attack followed.
Entry.144: Quite all day. Heavy thunder at 5 pm. rained very heavily for ½hr big black cloud like the water spout. our artillery opened at 11.45 p.m. about 200 shells came back in return. No casualties.
Entry.145: Warm & fine all day. about 60 shells came over at 10.0 midday. Artillery opened again on trenches in front. no sleep now for 3 nights and very little during days. Our artillery opened again at 11.0 p.m. & 1.0 a.m. retaliation bought about 300-400 shells.
Entry.146:
No sleep during last night continual bombardment today threw over 20 5.9" in one spot. shock of explosion caused 

40

pains in both ears. raid coming off to-night opposite our coy sector my platoon is stopping in firing line others gone back to reserve. commencing at 11.30 p.m. retaliation will be severe. Germans must know something is coming off and will have preparations made. Have now bombarded same spot for 3 days in succession. Artillery opened at 11.30 p.m. fired heavily for 40 minutes. raid a success captured 4 prisoners casualties 1 killed & 7 severely wounded. nobody wounded in trenches wonderful when consider number of shells that passed overhead & hit parapet. get numb after a while from shock of explosions. I was partially deaf for sometime afterwards & had headache. some of craters 6 ft deep by 15ft across.
Entry.147:
Rained slightly artillery active on both sides. had narrow escape

41

was just getting up from chair in mess when something made me sit down. a minute afterwards 2 bombs exploded in Anderson’s dugout. I was going into his dugout to get one. it was caused by a piece of shrapnel containing phosphorous exploding which set off a german bomb captured last night. 8.30 pm 3 hostile baloons set on fire by incendary bombs dropped from planes, 2 baloons destroyed in similar manner last night. Enemy opened very heavy artillery fire on us at 10.30 p.m. as a diversion and raided 6 Bge. raid repulsed enemy loosing 28 killed by raiding party. at 11.20 we opened fire for 10 minutes at 12.30 a.m. opened again with all guns & sent over raiding party from 18ty Batt. took 2 prisoners. 2 inch motar did wonderful work at cutting wire cut lane 50 yds long & 10 ft forward to enemy parapet at range of 300 yds estimate that 

42

during last 4 days germans have thrown at us 20,000 shells. we had no casualties & parapet breached in 3 places. In a bombardment if men lie down under fire step with one man on watch we should be able to stop a german raid.
Entry.148: very quiet all day rainy. my platoon & No. 5 relieved at 11 p.m. by 14 Batt going to Fort Rompu for rest which is badly needed by all hands, majority of men are badly rattled.
Entry.149: very quiet all day relieved by remainder of 14 Batt at 11 p.m. just got into Tramway Av when artillery started none our way, reached For Rompu 1.30 am turned out. billeted in Church.
Entry.150: Changed our billet for cottages on road. Fine country round here looks beautiful. English advance at La Bassee.
Entry.151:
paraded at 9 am bayonet fighting in afternoon saw no less than 24 plates up of all sizes. Said to be 61 divisions in fighting at La Bassee 30 English 31 French bombed Lille railway stn.

43

Took fatigue party to trenches laid cable 16 strands in trench 5’6" x 2"4 under m.gun fire all time lost one man hit Walker No. 8 in back arrived billet 2.0 a.m. after walking 10 miles all told
Entry.152: quiet all day. practice in bomb throwing won 20 Fr. Heavy artillery fire at 10.30 on both sides. put in application for Div. Gas officer.
Entry.153:
Fine all day. 14th Batt last night failure raided end of Sec. 57 mistook objective & came under own covering fire. 30 casualties. Saw 
Bge Major
 Major Anderson present gas officer & had talk.
Entry.154: Fine. Saw Bge Major I had not been recommended as Bge thought I was not keen on getting position impression given by Col. MacKenzie unfortunate as I wanted position for Mum’s sake.
Entry.155:
Rained heavily went to Division to see if could alter things. Div. Hg moved to Neuve Eglise but Capt Burns (ginger) is getting to see A.D.M.S. may get something out of it. Last night Germans raided

44

Sec. 56 & 57 Lewis guns saved situation one gun crew recommended. Germans lost heavily in our wire 5 got in trench but were immediately pushed out.
Entry.156:
wet & muddy. Spend a lot of time drinking coffee & talking french to lady in whose house we are billetted. She has two very nice little girls 12 & 14 yrs. none of family has seen the sea. surprised at distance Australia is away. Cant understand how a ship can carry enough food for 30 days.

We have had successes on Somme cavalry said to be loose if we can keep moving will make wonderful difference to end of war. It is reported today that the way is open to the Somme & that the French Cavalry have traversed the country.
Entry.157:
Fine & quiet all day, detailed for bayonet fighting school

45

reported to Bge 6.30 p.m. billetted in Erquinheim, good billets mess with 418th Batt officers Caddell one of them. Blacket the other
Entry.158:
man with me had row with Manifield of 17th used my tongue to good effect.

8
Entry.159: School commences 9 a.m very strenuous & is on top floor of string factory of large size. General Holmes & Major Viney visited school in afternoon put up second star.
Entry.160:
Fine all day. physical drill & bayonet exercises all day. received order to report to Batt. immediately left Erquinheim 8 p.m. Reported to Batt at 10 p.m. slept in old billett at Fort Rompu.

9/7/16

Reveille 6 a.m. left Fort Rompu 8.390 am passed through Bac St. Main, Croix du Bac, Steenwerk, Stragella Erquinheim billetted at steenwerk arriving there 4.0 p.m. very tired. slept well in farm house, Some very sore feet in platoons, destination unknown.

46
Entry.161: Left billet 10.0 am moving by Coy’s 5 minute interval passed through Borre, Hayebrouch, Nallon Chappel billeted just outside. latter place in farm house. The country round here with different shades of green in the crops, the hedges, trees, dark green and red roofed houses present a most beautiful picture. Received orders to have all blankets rolled in 20s by 7.45 p.m. did yesterday 25 kilometres & today 14 kilometres. French Village example of cleanliness.
Entry.162:
Fine left billet 8.30 a.m. marched until 4.30 p.m. passing through arcques to siding just outside St. Omer last 2 mls under huge cliffs of 
lime
 chalk. Took train from siding at 6.0 p.m passed through Calais, Boulougne, Amiens & detrained at Saleux at 3.0 am.
Entry.163:
Had breakfast at 5.0 am just outside station. there we were passed by a Bge of French infantry on the way to the trenches 20 mls away.

47

commenced march at 7.0 am arrived at billets in village of Picquigny on the banks of the Somme at 1.0 p.m after marching 20 kilometres. River here narrows and flows very fast. an old Chateau stands on the right bank. Some of finest scenery I have seen is to be had here. I am billeted in house of a vetinary Surgeon, & very comfortable. Will probably do some Training in street & bush fighting before proceeding to the trenches 30 miles away. The main railway Boulougne – Paris is on the banks of Somme had good swim in large water hole this afternoon.
Entry.164:
Orderly Officer for the day. near here are large waterholes cont. plenty of fish and wild fruit. tried to get some ducks with stones without success. ducks very tame. English have taken 2nd line of trenches and part of third we will go 

48

into it as soon as third line is taken will probably be open order fighting will be very acceptable are 3 months trench warfare. Gave phonograph to old lady in this village, the daughter I think really got the phonograph.
Entry.165:
Fine day drill in morning route march in the afternoon, got 2 bombs and landing net to bomb fish in river, weighed myself in a 
cotton
 rope mill weighed 12 st 2 lbs.
Entry.166:
Fine bayonet drill in morning swim in afternoon. visited an old chateau, the Chateau of Picquigny where peace was signed at the conclusion of the 100 years war after the battle of Agincourt in 1425. Had our photos taken, B coy officers, in the grounds next to the Chapel. Very fine view 
of the
 from the chapel. Some fine paintings inside 900 yrs old. Rec. 4 letters from home 29/5/16.

49
Entry.167:
Rec. orders to move at 10.20 p.m. left Picquigny 12 midday passed through Ailly on the Somme, crossed river here. Longri Poulainville and billeted at Coisy doing 11 mls up to 4.30pm passed around 
southern
 northern end of Amiens. Can hear guns in distance.
Entry.168: good news from front. British still advancing. Indian Cavalry doing good work. Longeval taken. Misty rain most of day.
Entry.169: Rained in morning left billets at 1.0 p.m. passed through Pierregot, Rubempre and billeted in Herissart. Batt. led astray after leaving Rubempre did 2 mls extra did in all 8½ mls. arrived Hiressart 4.30 p.m. country getting more hilly, can hear heavy firing towards Fricourt firing line about 10 mls away.
Entry.170:
Stayed in Herissart all day, went for walk at night towards Loutencourt very peaceful. 200 light horse passed through at 5.00 pm.

50
Entry.171: Left Herissart 9.30 a.m. marched through Contay, Vadencourt billeted at Walloy-Baillon . Hear guns plainly. 1st Div. in trenches around Poiyeres . Had several casualties. warm during day.
Entry.172: Fine drilled all day teaching men Semaphore, getting 2 lewis guns per company. It will be my job to look after the 2 guns.
Entry.173: Fine, wrote letter to Pa for his birthday. Left Billet at 6.0 p.m. arrived outside Albert and bivouaced. Night extremely cold.
Entry.174: Remained on bivouac ground all day. Visited original British front line with Wallach. German dugout wonderful. Last night 1st Div took ¾ of Pozieres, remainder of village evacuated in morning of 23rd attack a complete success. French captured Peronne advance going splendidly (incorrect)
Entry.175:
Moved up to orig British line at head of Sausage Valley. We have uncontested aerial superiority. Also in Artillery which is splendid.

51

25
Entry.176:
spent night in Front line german trenches. slept in shell hole with swallow a Sherman. 60 P. battery fired 50 yds away, could not sleep had only G.coat & w.proof, very cold. Poizeres taken.

25/7/16

Spent day in looking at German dugouts, are upward of 25 ft deep & have tables, chairs etc. as well as electric light installed. Relieved 1st Div. left valley 8.45 p.m. Found 12th Batt. in an awful position through constant shelling front line was a chain of shell holes, took over as well as we could & then waited for dawn. German started to shell 12.0 midnight heavily. 
spent
Entry.177:
Today has been an awful day valley mass of H.C. & shrapnel, all work done under this fire, the front saps contain a lot of our unburried wounded arrive at dressing station in one continual stream, losses today 200 about 13 officers, my platoon has lost 8, 1 missing. The most awful day I have put in

52
Entry.178:
Helping to carry a wounded man down to dressing station, fell into hole and got bad sprain – cant go away with it very well yet I am useless here. 1 shrap got 14 men, my platoon is in reserve No. 8 have an old german dug-out. don’t like being under cover when 
can
 have time when men in open. All your determination breaks down at times & you want to get away. we are attempting to bomb fritz out of his third line, don’t know with what success. Artillery firing very heavy after can be seen burned & without heads etc.
Entry.179:
Still shelling heavily, valley mass of schrapnel became less intense during afternoon. All german shooting done by map as he has got no observation, went out at night to dig new trench to east of Poizieres lost going out, had to return lost 2 men in doing so. Sent out runners to find place, before they returned was ordered to take the men (100) out.

53

refused until runners returned. Major Walker ordered me again & took lead had gone about 200 yds when some shells fell on us. Walker bolted & left men, went back and I bandaged up some wounded in a shell hole. got my bearing & brought them back. One shell burst right in front of me wounding 4 & killing all round me. After got back went out 
on my own
 with Sgt. Macdermot & 2 men found new trench. Came back with Capt Sherbon lost again owing to thick smoke from shells, put men into old trench, went & found our trench returned with men. Absolutely exhausted one long night-mare.

29/7/16

Fairly quiet during day. 6th &
Entry.180:
Bges attacked at night, barb wire not out & attack held up, had to return lost heavily from m. gun fire. One shell burst on parapet in front of me. Killed 5 & wounded one. eyes burnt from flash of shell, dressed wounded man & cleared dead from trench. Swallow badly rattled, he was with me when shell burst. 

54

our officers lost to date are Killed Heritage, Donaldson, Wounded Bell also Kemnis wounded Scott, Forsyth, Weedon, Douglass, Blackett (badly) leg somewhat better, also Hodgsen, died later.
Entry.181:
Quiet during day, Swallow went to dug-out for sleep. Cap. Sherbon took over front line 2 heavy bombardment during night. At 1.0 am received orders from H.Q, to reinforce front line, practically an impossibility, judging from the amt of fire and lack of m. gun fire that front line did not want support. did not reinforce but sent out runners to get situation. runners lost so after ½ hr sent word to H.Q. that situation was normal & Sherbon needed no help. Luckily this turned out to be correct. Our signal for help was red parachute flare, Sadler had seen german red flare go up & had given the alarm. Was commended by Major Norrie on actions taken. The Australian army though made up of wonderful

55

men have very few competent officers in higher places. As shown by the lack of preparation & foresight in the attack etc. To my mind men who bring about needless sacrifice of lives by negligence should be turned out immediately. gas shells are used in large numbers.
Entry.182: Fine day large No. of aeroplanes up. Men feeling strain of continued shell fire, the
Entry.183: 36 hrs in trenches was an incessant bombardment. Dug-out mentioned above was blown in early this morning and wounded Swallow both legs, Boyden, Walker & Bignell slight, Watson & Harlum were also wounded, Wilson severely leg & arm. My pack ratted & lost flask, notebook & aluminium mug. Had given diary to Anderson who was sent back to Sausage Valley before the attack.
Entry.184:
Have lost account of times & dates. Batt. has lost to date officers 400 men, mostly slight wounds, very bad smell of dead mean makes you sick. Working parties were held up in sap owing to shell fire & 

57

Batt. officers dont go round among the men but pick out safe spot & stop there.
Entry.185: dead lying all over trenches lost heavily.
Entry.186: Rec. 3 letters from home. furnished digging parties. attack to-night if successful will move out of valley tomorrow. Rec. orders at 2.30 p.m. to report to Bg. to take charge of a dump for forwarding material to the front line. Sent up material throughout the attack which proved a complete success. Capturing both lines of trenches and 400 prisoners. Germans made 3 counter attack all unsuccessful. Fritz fights only with artillery no good at hand-to-hand work.
Entry.187:
Returned to Valley at 12.30 p.m. had a wash & much needed sleep, being relieved to-night. sent cable home. Left Sausage Valley at 9.30 p.m. bivouaced on ridge just outside A in full view of Albert. Far different are my thoughts now than 10 days ago.

 Tara Hill

58

Saw Stan told me that Bruce was killed with shell on 2/8/16.
Entry.188: Reviewed by Gen. Birdwood in morning. gave speech said we were going back to refit and then into it again. Left bivouac position 12.30 p.m. & arrived at Nalloy-Baillon at 7.0 p.m. hot dusty march, foot very painful. Can say that for the present we are safe.
Entry.189: Stayed at Walloy all day could hear heavy firing in distance, had much needed sleep. Shifted billets higher up village into very nice cottage.
Entry.190: Left Walloy 10.0 am arrived at La Vicogne 5.30 p.m. bivouac in old orchard. March very hot & dusty. Saw Stan, looked well. Will ask him to Tea when possible.
Entry.191:
Left orchard at 10.0 am marched to Pernois where we billetted, passed through Talmar & Canaples, later village nestled in valley very pretty. houses mostly slate roofs

59

water supply from spring, comes out in centre of road, water beautifully clear. wrote letter to Pa.
Entry.192: Birthday today, wrote to Mum, acted as O.C. divisional baths in afternoon. billet very clean and has splendid view. have on my bed clean sheets & pillow slip, very comfortable.
Entry.193: Fine all day. Batt. still resting, took party to baths.
Entry.194:
had chicken for dinner in afternoon had enquiry into loss of poultry in our area. Enquiry sent in nil report. Orderly Officer. Fine summer day, cool breeze blowing.

12/8/16

View from billet better than ever, situated high up on side of valley, looks across to other side, went to communion in the morning, also church at 11.0 a.m.
Entry.195:
Rec. orders 9.0 a.m. to take piquet to Vignacourt. Arrived there at 10.45 a.m. reported 
at
 to Town major. Provided with

60

billet and men with 2 tents, rations, splendid men satisfied as work is light and rest ample. duty from 4.-39 – 9.0 pm every night. I am billeted in an estaminet. The daughter is fine well-educated good-looking girl. Speaks English well, a real pleasure to speak to her. After 8.0 p.m. when estaminet closes, talked for couple of hours about Australian life as compared with French. Aught to be able to improve my French will try, name Marguerite. Same as Mims baby. Learnt today that casualties in 1st Anzac corps up to
Entry.196: have been 25,000. Rec. letter from Wilson, he has lost left leg below knee. Sent him 100 Fr. will write to Pa and see if he can help him to get employment. Feel very lonely and homesick tonight I suppose it is a reaction after what I have been through.
Entry.197:
Spent another very pleasant day went for a walk towards

61

Amiens very fine view from Hill close by. men have more rations than they can eat, draw straight from supply. Rec. orders 11.0 p.m. to proceed with 4 men to Longpre to stop men going into Amiens.
Entry.198: Left Vignacourt 7.50 arrived Longpre-Amiens 10.30 am. no R.T.O. decided was wrong place. took train to Longpre les Corps Saints report to R.T.O. arrived 1.30 p.m. stopped No of 6 Bge but let them get on train. Had passes signed by Drummond. Billeted in good big house, met French girl who could speak English rather weak, so not of much interest.
Entry.199:
Had good nights sleep caught a 6 Bgd m. gunner with same pass as others had yesterday. detained them & wired H.Q. for orders. Sent all prisoners on to Batt. as no escort arrived. Went for swim with R.T.O. can borrow bike whenever require it.

62
Entry.200:
Went fishing in the morning with Belgian refugees we caught 2 small fish had them for tea. In afternoon went for a bike ride west as far as Pont-Remy. Rode along Canal all the way. Scenery beautiful with canal in Rv Somme on one side & marshes on the other. Some fine houses on banks but rather unkempt. returned for Tea. Rec. orders to join Batt on morrow, went for another ride at 8.0 p.m. along canal in opposite direction. Took wrong road was directed by 2 girls, stood talking for some time. 
They
 One was brown slight and healthy Kissed them both good-bye, arrived home 10.0 p.m. had good nights sleep.
Entry.201:
Took train to Canaples sent man to Vignacourt for rest of Piquet found that they had departed for Batt. arranged to get transport to Walloy Baillon tomorrow at 6.30 am. 

63

got good billets for myself & men. Two very nice girls in mine, played cards with them, the first time I have done so in France. Batt. moved 2 days ago. Sam Roy North & (Lance Young)
Entry.202: Left Canaples 7.0 a.m. by motor waggon. nice clear morning had very pleasant drive to Vadencourt where I found the Batt. Left with Batt at 10.30 a.m for Albert arrived there 4 p.m. had tea B then moved to Sausage Valley. Great change in Valley most of guns moved up closer & less transport about. bivouacked the night there. feel a dread of going in again.
Entry.203:
Had good sleep last night though cold. 6 Hun planes came over and dropped 2 bombs wounded m. gun sergeant & 2 men. bomb gives horrible feeling of helplessness as cant tell where it is going to fall. Left valley at 7.0 p.m. for front line. A & B Coys in reserve & C & D in front line. Took over line behind Long Drive. Had good sleep.

64
Entry.204: Front much quieter very little shelling. Front line dug 50 yds from edge of plateau overlooking Corcelette & Martinpuich. Hun cant shoot on front line drops them in his own trench when he tries. Hun line at nearest ft – 40 yds away. At night took working party to front line to dig communications trench. was heavily shelled, lost 1 man. dug line in spite of shells line full of dead bodies. returned at 12.30 a.m.
Entry.205:
Had quiet day at 5.0 p.m. received an order to report to 44th Bge as liason officer at Contalmaison. Shelled heavily while going through village reported at 7.30 p.m. relieved Porter of 18th Batt. Officers on Bge. all permanent men seen service in India & Africa. Brigadier Gen. Marshall, B.M. Major Back. Very nice men & made me quite at home. Large dug-out & slept well every night. Duties here are as a connecting link between 

65

the two Bges to ensure co-operation in any attack etc that may take place.
Entry.206: Reported to Bge for news & received letter from Home from Coy. Sherbon is now a Major. He deserved it. Return to 44 & reported progress of our work.
Entry.207: Should have been relieved to go as A & B Coy. went into line but was told to continue. Rec. letter from Min Elliot & birthday billy from Mum it was very acceptable indeed. tin of ginger made me think of Dorothy & home.
Entry.208:
Sgt. James & Essex were killed while going into line last night. feel like a deserter at not being with platoon.

27/8/16

Rained most of day. Batt. relieved by 7th Bge in night. Coy shelled heavily when coming out luckily no casualties. My relief from 7th Bge did not turn up. Had good nights sleep.

66
Entry.209: 7th Bge officer turned up at 1.30 a.m. this morning. I had good breakfast and said good-bye and left in a car with the mess secretary “Ginger" for Walloy where I considered the Batt would arrive that night, found
Entry.210: Bge there went on to Vadencourt then to Contay & enquired at Corps H.Q. where Batt was found. they were still at Albert, returned there by means of motor waggons & found Batt at 1.30 p.m. Bivouacked night at Brickfield’s Hill outside Albert. Allan Smith killed, his brother as well.
Entry.211:
Left Brickfields 8.0 a.m. arrived Walloy-Baillon 11.30 a.m. Same billet as first time. officers now in B. Coy include 3 of our Sergeants Gun, Stewart & Blake, 3 good men. Anderson a Capt & O.C. D. Coy. Blumon gone to C. Coy & Swallow wounded. Original lot pretty well split up. Wilson has lost both legs. May get a staff job on Bge if lucky.

67
Entry.212: Rained heavily all day. At night A Coy. officers came down and drank whisky. I went to bed about 12.30 a.m. 2 English & 1 Scotch officer came in & very soon all were badly drunk. Marshall Adjuntant was drunk & made a fool of himself. While drunk he told Dent all he had done to stop Dent’s promotion. Marshall has absolutely no principles & would think nothing of injuring a man so long as he was himself advanced.
Entry.213: Reported to A Coy as second in command. Harrison is O.C. don’t think much of him somewhat on same level & as Marshall I think. However can get on with him if I like. Left Walloy 1.30 p.m. Passed through Heressart, then to Val-de-maison & billeted in Beauval at 8.0 p.m. Have good billet.
Entry.214:
Fine day, had charge of Coy. in afternoon for drill. Had tea with B. Coy. at 8.0 p.m. in a hotel, good dinner, got home 11.30 p.m.

68
Entry.215: Duty Coy. inspected billets etc. wrote letters home, had nice quiet day. Have got a good orderly a barber named Burgen, one time practicing in Castlereagh St Sydney.
Entry.216: Church parade in morning sent home some cards views of Armentieres & Albert. Had talk with Stan and saw Chappie. Received news that I was to go to a month’s school on the 9th at Wisker near St. Omer. Peter Graham was killed near Chalk pit – Sausage Valley.
Entry.217:
Went in an ambulance with Chappie, James and Sutton to “Les Souterrains" at Naours. Well worth seeing. 
built
 excavated by inhabitants of village as a refuge against raiding parties in 850 A.D. and have been used in 10, 13 & 16 centuries in the various wars. One time against Price Thomas of Spain. Have been visited by Malborough 

69

and other well known people. Also by John Norton & Eva Pannet of Clapham England in a later times by many Australia Soldiers. saw Rod Macalphine’s name up as Lt. 4th Batt. 
leaving
 Borrowed ambulance from Col. Phipps without his knowledge and met him in caves. Rather embarrassing. Leaving here tomorrow for Hayebrouch by train from Doullens.
Entry.218:
Left Beauval 11.45 a.m. arrived Doullens 1.30 p.m. had coffee in canteen served by french voluntary aide lovely girl. All girls look lovely after trench life. Train left at 3.15 p.m. passed through St. Pol to Hazebrouck then to Hopoutic siding outside Poperinge at 10.0 p.m. billeted in Poperinge, fine town largest have been in, large buildings aparantly factories. Town very well stocked with provisions. Has canteens, Y.M.C.A. and Picture show. Some pictures some of which had seen in 

70

Mosman. This is our first appearance in Belgium.
Entry.219: Had quiet day. Strolled around town bought fr. by serviette rings for Mum. Money very short here at present.
Entry.220: Inspected Gas Helmets & rifles this afternoon & talked to new N.C.O.s in position of 2nd in command. must try & get company properly organised. went to Picture show this afternoon very good pictures shown. Sent letter home containing german badges to Pa, Maji & Dorothy. Got letter from Alice & Heymound. Makes me feel nasty getting letters from Alice. I think it is better not to reply though would like to very much, feel like a cad sometimes. Very hard to know what to do.
Entry.221:
Nice fine day, no parades. visited another picture show at night a concert was on varied with pictures good 

71

performance. Received word that I was to go to an army school at Wisques 2 miles outside St. Omer. This school is supposed to fit you for a company command. Hope it does.
Entry.222:
Batt left at 7.30 p.m. tonight for Ypres where it is in reserve 17th & 18th Batt. take front line. did not like them doing without me. Many latrines prevalent whether we are staying here for winter or not. If we do stay I think there will be a large no of sick when winter sets in. Rec. parcel from Min Elliot & also from Alice. Also got one from Alice yesterday. It is a great pity that when the men here are giving their lives, or if not their lifes 10 or 20 years of it for their country, the politicians or men so called cannot pull together and do their bit by trying to make Australia self contained in regard to munitions. It seems to me the only remedy is to have one house of parliament

72

and put in that house men who have had the training to look ahead and see what is before them. It seems also that Aust. has made an irreparable mistake in attempting to put in the field 5 divisions, the loss of which it can ill afford.
Entry.223:
Left Poperinghe by 6.15 a.m. train changed at Hazebrouck took train at 8.05 a.m for St. Omer. Had dinner in town & then walked to Wisques 3 mls away. School in an old convent of perhaps 200 rooms fitted with mess & reading room in the grounds which are heavily wooded and a Y.M.C.A. recreation tent billiard tables and another reading room with a piano & small concert platform. There are 3 of us in a room. Our three are Harris a Canadian, a man from the 5th Div. and myself. At the school are Canadians Scotch English Irish & Australian a very fine lot indeed.

73
Entry.224: First parade at 9.30 a.m. squad drill & rifle exercises very regimental. Had lecture on Esprit da Coeur
Entry.225: Early morning parade 7.0 a.m. physical jerks, ceremonial parade every morning at 9.30 a.m. stripped to waist for physical ex. lecture at 6 p.m. on aeroplane maps & observation. In the room opposite me is Bill Harris who joined the 5th Div in room with me are Lt. Harvie G9 Canadian Batt & Walton of 5 Div.
Entry.226: Riding drill in early morning then lecture on Engineering with practical demonstrations. Went to St. Omer in afternoon had good time, have felt depressed last couple of days & dread going back to line again. Sometimes I feel as if must get out of it at any price & get gas job & then at times want to stick to it. sent cable.
Entry.227:
Physic drill, fire disciple etc. lecture. Lecture at 6 p.m. on machine guns one of best I have heard in selecting line for defense

74

selecting gun position & then join up with fire trench. Captured line must be held with lewis and vickers & as few men as possible, use men as patrols between gun positions. seems to be here a feeling of antipathy against Australians by the staff.
Entry.228:
Phy. drill & rapid wiring with rifle exercises put in application to go on leave to Calais over week end. last night the cinema in the Y.M.C.A. was working & showed some very good pictures. At the end of course there is to be a sports meetings and I am very much afraid my ankle will come against me. I hope it does not as it would be nice to win from a crowd like this. Have a band here now which is very acceptable. Rec. 2 letters from Home from Marjorie & Pa. The sights I have seen come before me now more than when they happened. Staff here think that we will get open fighting here shortly.

75
Entry.229: Physical drill & map reading. Went to Boulougne in afternoon with Bill Harris, stayed at Hotel Folkestone overlooking Quay. Had hot bath went to bed early.
Entry.230: Had breakfast went to No. 2 H.G.H. Wimereux met 2 nurses. Hadaway and Harpford took them to dinner in Boulougne & then went to old Cathedral. Afterwards sat on beach & listed to band. Caught 4.15 p.m. train back to St. Omer. Could not get garrey out to school started to walk. stopped one and made it go back with us. Also met nurse Mosey very nice.
Entry.231: Bayonet fighting rained all day had lectures. Lecture at 6 p.m. by Prof. Atkin from Cambridge on Balkan triangle, very fine lecture. Very pleasant to listen to a man who speaks well.
Entry.232:
Rained most of day. Bayonet fighting and lecture. Prof. Atkin spoke again on England’s position in war.

76
Entry.233: Usual routine, more engineering. Football match in afternoon. Aust. beaten by 11-0, ground very uneven & grass long. Lecture at night by Prof Atkin on Russia, will send Pa typewritten copies of lectures. Find it extremely hard to get up in the morning, don’t know whether it is result of hard times or fatness. Rec. letter from Mabel Wallace.
Entry.234: Rained during day. Had run to get in training for sports doubt if foot will stand strain. Band concert at night.
Entry.235: Rec. letter from George who is in England & and has had enteric. Lecture on Intelligence. Sam McCullum & Light horse man from Euipedes. Picture show at night. Attack over ground between Wisques & Moringham mill in morning. nothing in afternoon.
Entry.236:
Bill Harris went to doctor about leg may go to hosp. 

77

Consolidation of a crater in morning. beautiful day. Riding this afternoon enjoyed it thoroughly as learnt to trot for first time. Went for bike ride with Harvie from B.I of Commerce Canada Winnipeg this afternoon.
Entry.237: Fine day. Rode into St. Omer for some money. Spent afternoon in writing letters, wrote to Dr. Covlesey, Min Elliot, Min Blackburn, Joyce, Dorothy & Mum. George has had enteric & Eric Leash killed. Letter from George.
Entry.238: Drill as usual. Went for ride in afternoon on horses to Boisdinghem with Carrolin. Had afternoon tea at farm house.
Entry.239: carried out attack in morning very hot, cinema at night.
Entry.240: Rode into St. Omer in garry. On return saw Roydhouse who is adjutant 28th. Lecture on strategy by Joffre.
Entry.241:
Drill day misty, consolidation of crater practice. Revolver shooting.

78

got 1st place won sweep stake of 10F. Lecture on Trench mortars.
Entry.242: Drill again & misty. Did road reconnaisance in morning. Lecture on Russia at night 6 p.m.
Entry.243: Fine slight attack of tonsilitis, gas demonstration by Capt Barley. Spoke to Bawley & wrote him a letter giving qualifications & address & something may come of it. Went to Calais in afternoon. large town more people about streets than Boulogne.
Entry.244: Went to beach & saw chalk cliffs of dover in distance. Spent day on beach looking at people. Returned to school 10 p.m.
Entry.245: Rainy weather set in concert at night sent programme home.
Entry.246:
Lecture & practical demonstration on demolition. Rail cut in two by 1 slah. (1 lb) gun cotton used with primer of Gc. & detonation. No. 6 Electric ignition by means of No. 13 mk iu detonator small piece Po. wire bet. terminals on to quick match

79

when used under water primer detonator & part of fuse under water covered in skin fuse used in this case. Safer to light joined to piece of instantaneous. Concert at night.
Entry.247: trench mortar demonstration 2" only one fired. Saw heavy mounted 2" fired with & without silencer. cinema show at night went to St. Omer in afternoon, bought art postcards to send home.
Entry.248:
Rainy weather. 
heats put off went to St. Omer in afternoon
 got tooth stopped at No. 10 General in St. Omer in morning. Heats in afternoon. Our team won relay race & I got 3rd in long jump beaten by 3".
Entry.249:
Bayonet fighting in 
afternoon
 morning. L. afternoon won relay, second in 440 yds & also in winning team of boat race, got writing case, gold & amber cigarette holder.

80

and a penknife. Nearly everybody drunk by 12 midnight.
Entry.250: Speech by commandant left school 9.55 changed train at Hazebrouck arrived at Godewaersvelde 6.30 walked to Steinvoorde & rejoined Batt. Marshall left 3 weeks ago with piles & Harrison left also both in England wont return. Douglass evacuated with weak heart. Bill Heath and Scott have returned. Scott has done only 3 weeks active service in France, in hosp most of the time had no right to return. Learnt lot at school both in regard to the lectures & mixing with men who were there.
Entry.251: Sadler is in command of Coy. does not make an ideal O.C. spent day in looking around no drills visited Steinvoorde.
Entry.252:
Left Billet 10.30 a.m. & found billet in 3 farm 

81

houses ½ way between Cassel and Winneszeiler have a tent to myself.
Entry.253: Had inspection of rifles. The officers we have are not particularly keen on drill & don’t make very good instructors. Langham & myself are the only 2 reinforcement officers and are the only two that know the drill. Sadler is going to the school at Wisques & while away I am going to ask for the Coy.
Entry.254: Commenced parades 7 – 7.30, 9.30 – 11.30 & 2 – 4 if given a clear month will have a good company by end of that time.
Entry.255: commenced practicing for football matches, bought 2 balls, 1 rugby & a soccer.
Entry.256: men already showing vast improvement in drill. Had practice match, put up posts & flags for rugby field.
Entry.257:
½ holiday played D. Coy rugby & soccer won Rugby by 8 – 3.

82

lost soccer 4 – 0. Rec. orders to move to Wisques to act as Batt. attached to 2nd army school. Sadler & Burke leave tomorrow for schools, will be in command of Coy.
Entry.258: Left billet at 7.30 a.m. marked to Godewausvelde & entrained to St. Omer, arrived at Tatinghem 1330 pm beautiful day though cold.
Entry.259: Voted on referendum, think result will be a no. wrote letter home giving my views. hard to say whether I am right or wrong.
Entry.260: Left for Suenvoorde for courtmartial sorry to leave as company was getting good.
Entry.261: Sat on court all day, whether fine pity to be indoors.
Entry.262: Rained most of day, finished court in afternoon.
Entry.263:
Arrived back at Tatingham. Took the Coy out 

83

to practice an attack to be made before the school tomorrow. Rather a compliment to 
have
 be put in charge of a company for show purpose, got on all right. Had full complement of officers, made up from D & B & C companies.
Entry.264: Attack a huge success. Major Norrie & Adjutant went out to see the show. Used semaphore signallers for intercommunication, worked perfectly. Major said it was best show he had ever seen. Bge have asked for a report on it.
Entry.265: Fine day went for ride to Lumbries football matches going well.
Entry.266: Left Touringhem at 5 p.m. arriving there 11.0 pm joined Langham rained all the way (Leighton & Fletcher joined)
Entry.267:
Moved to Audruicq by road where we entrained for Pont Remy.

84

A Coy started 2 hrs ahead of Batt. very dark but made no mistakes regarding roads, entrained at 10/30 pm.
Entry.268: Detrained this morning at Pont Remy at 8.0 am. marched 2½ mls to Cocerel rained all way very small village not much to eat & none too clean.
Entry.269: Slept well. Received orders at 6 a.m. to be ready to move at 8 a.m. Batt. marched to Heilly where after waiting 2 hrs in pouring rain the whole division boarded motor lorries 270 in all and proceed via Flexicourt, Picquigny, Amiens to Ribemont where we billeted for the night. Left at 1 p.m. & billeted at 9 p.m. Took 8 hours to do 35 mls, arrangements made by Bge for billeting poor had to do it ourselves. A Coy officers slept on chairs next to a small fire in an estaminet for the night.
Entry.270:
Fixed up billets for ourselves, no work ground too soft rained

85

continually all day. Colonel returned to Batt. Sherbon & Blumer also returned had grand time cost them about £20 per day.
Entry.271: Rained all day roads in frightful state. Frank Burke returned from Lewis Gun school. At Albert he saw nothing but troops evidently on their way for a shot at Bapaume. 1st Div. left Albert for trenches today.
Entry.272: Sunday. Church service could not be held owing to rain. 3 officers & 120 men from this Batt. went to Albert to do work at a concentration camp.
Entry.273: Still raining. no word yet of moving.
Entry.274: Showery, drilled all day, first day for some time.
Entry.275: Fine, rifle exercises in morning, practised attack for tomorrow in afternoon 4 lines Coy attack a success.
Entry.276:
Rained in morning, attack to take place in 4 lines. Batt. frontage

86

280 yds. 1st line ½ A Coy + ½ B. Coy. 2nd line 1 rt A L m.g. + stretcher bearers + same for B Coy. 3rd line, 3 Rt’s of C Coy + 4th 3 Pts of D Coy. bombers to follow 2nd & 3rd waves. 4 lines followed by vickers guns & stokes mortars, then remaining platoons as carrying parties. Objective 3 lines of german trenches 1 & 2 waves 1st German lines, 3 & 4 waves for O.G. 2 & 3 consolidate o.g. 3 & push out in front strong posts as beginning of new front line. Coy lewis guns on flank of Coy’s all lines told off into trench cleaners & moppers up. Attack cancelled. Reported that 5th Div. lost 800 men with pneumonia.
Entry.277: Attack took place this morning a complete success, no drill in afternoon anticipating a move.
Entry.278:
Moved to Mametz wood where we are billeted in huts.

87

whole place a sea of mud. Railways have been built right through here. Heavy firing heard tonight, reported that 1 Batt. lost 600 from sickness mostly pneumonia and another reported unfit for duty, expect that our men will soon begin to fall out. Scott has taken over command of A Coy, but will probably not last very long.
Entry.279:
Fatigues have started for the Batt. & it is unlikely that we shall go into the lines this time, it rains continuously and is very cold. The road up to the front about 4 mls through Montauban is one line of bog holes & whole way is littered with dead horses and all kinds of transport. From this wood can be seen Debuille wood Fricourt High & all the places included in the first push. The whole countryside is one large camp with numerous railways running through them.

88
Entry.280: 7th Bge went over yesterday & gained objective. Fritz cannot be seen, though our artillery is very active shooting far behind the lines. At 11. p.m. several Tanks came over & dropped a few bombs. Major Norrie & 3 men went on leave, seems that no more officers to go until we come out of the line. B. Coy still consumes large quantities of whiskey & it will be interesting to see the effect when we take the line next time.
Entry.281: Raining very heavily & extremely cold. We are attached to the 7th Bge to do fatigue duty. They have lost very heavily from weather conditions we lose over 20 a day & our men are in huts at night feet wet all day long.
Entry.282:
waited all day for order to move. Left Mametz at 8.30 p.m. bright moon, showed up the road fairly well. Rd very muddy and very shell hole full of soft mud, a couple of men would 

89

slip into a shell hole and his mates have to to pull him out. Rd. littered with dead horses, broken limbers and motor waggons. Arrived at Carlton camp passing through Montauban at 12.0 p.m. the floor of every tent was a bog. There are four of us in this tent. Myself on an AMC stretcher. Bourke on a sheet of galvanised iron, Helms on a sheet of paper & Rouse on a biscuit tin with a candle inside, slept a little.
Entry.283: When awakened this morning had to feel for my legs, they were so cold. However today is fine for which we are thankful. Batt. moved off at 3.0 p.m. for front line to relieve 17 Batt. I as second in command was left behind with Dent, Major Sherbon took charge of the Batt and moved off. Major Walker returned but was evacuated and will not return again.
Entry.284:
This morning saw Allen of the 17th Batt & was told that Batt got in 

90

all right with only 3 casualties in “C:" Coy large numbers of 17th bad with feet and while in the trenches were up to their knees in slush. How men can stand it at all is wonderful. Father Clune came back this afternoon very tired. Stan went yesterday to England. Camp was shelled this afternoon the valley towards Fleurs & High Wood is a mass of guns 8" Howitzers and larger. Rations here have been very short, wood as well. Turned a small tin into a brazier & managed to partly dry our boots & socks at night.
Entry.285: Very cold and wet. The 17th Batt today evacuated 105 sick & trench feet men came in from front line just able to walk. very heavy firing last night, guns going night & day.
Entry.286:
Cloudy though fine went for a walk with Dent and the Padre as far as Bge H.Q. in front of Fleurs. Saw a tank, oval in shape about

91

30 ft long & 10 ft broad with pr of large iron wheels behind for steering, moved by an oil engine along centre inside & which works 2 endless chains around both sides. Chains are fitted with plates which dig into ground & drag it along fitted with 4 m.guns and 2 6pr guns, iron covering of sufficient strength to stop pieces of shells & bullets but not direct hits. Padre was wounded over the eye, not seriously. Bat. relieved by 26th Batt, 17 and 18 going into huts at Mametz & 20th to Carlton Camp. German artillery threw a large No. of smoke shells on support lines & to rear.
Entry.287:
went to switch trench in morning & saw battalion were very tired and sore footed. Very few casualties. Middleton going to a school so Dent took over C Company was Batt. was ordered to 

92

attack german front & support line at 6.45 am next morning. was looking forward to a lively time when at a meeting of the officers to discuss the operation I was told I would be liason officer to the 149th Bge who were attacking on our left. Rather a surprise when I had made up my mind to go over. must say I was not disappointed to any great extent. Had the same feeling as I had before the 2nd time in at Pozieres that all would be well. I left the Batt at 11.45 pm and proceeded across country. I arrived at Bge H.Q. very tired and wet & 1.15 a.m. and bunked in the mess room.

14/11/16

The artillery opened exactly at 6.45 a.m. and continued to fire heavily for 30’ when our barrage lifted to rear of second objective 300 yds. All communications with Bge at front line was cut by 9 a.m. The Batt. commanders of 5 & 7th Northumberland Fusiliers 

93

assumed that all was correct and did not worry with the result that at 2 p.m. there was no information through regarding front line. General Owen co. 149th Bge took me down to the Batt H.Q.’s of 5 & 7th Batt’s to straighten things out the result was that he ordered the Batt. Commanders to make a reconnaissance in force under their personal supervision. This attack which was ordered for 6.30 p.m. did not come off until after mid-night such was the congestion & lack of control in the front line & C.T.’s. When this attack was made it transpired that all the success of 
the
 early in the day had been retaken by the German probably at 11 a.m. when we knew he had counter attacked but did not know the result. The only part held was a small portion of the gird trench in conjunction with the
Entry.288:
A.I.F. Our Batt. gained both 

94

objectives and held on to them despite heavy counter attacks. They ran out of bombs and S.A.A. m guns & bombs which sufficed Major Sherbon was hit in stomach prior to the attack and died at the 6th Field D.S. bullet in the stomach. Anderson & Somerset & Burke were wounded and Stewart, Dent, Gurr & Helms killed. On returning to Bge H.Q. the General in trying to dodge some shrapnel twisted his ankle and I had to practically carry him for about 800 yds.
Entry.289:
Artillery practically ceased firing, reported to Bge & learnt that there were only 5 officers & 85 men left. Scott, Langham, Trennery, Griffin & Rouse. The Batt now stands at 250 & 10 officers including doctor & Colonel. Gathered up sick at switch trench & started off with Blumer for Mametz camp.

95

arriving there at 1 a.m. Had hot stew & tea. The remainder after having issue of rum & hot tea at switch trench which I had arranged for arrived at the camp at 6 a.m. dead beat.
Entry.290: Fine cold day, everybody slept practically all day long only awakening for meals.
Entry.291: Took Batt. down to the bathes for clothes, wind cutting ice 2" thick on all water holes & water in baths frozen, ice remained solid all day. Received 7 letters & parcel of socks from Marjorie. Bill Harris has been boarded for Australia.
Entry.292: Snow on ground about an inch very pretty looking over hills. Snow remained well into afternoon when it began to sleet. Moved up to Carlton Camp at 4.5 pm am now O.C. 1 coy. We marched out 57 strong & are the strongest Coy.
Entry.293:
Spent day mostly in bed very cold & misty a few shells came

96

over at night everybody has a bad cold.
Entry.294: Supplied fatigue party for Montauban. Langham had charge & had 2 casualities, dull & misty.
Entry.295: Left camp for Fricourt & arrived there 2.30 p.m. have good huts. Went to Meaulte to corps workshops to enquire about fatigues. Batt will be engaged on corps works for next few days. Have mislaid pack containing diary & over it had row with Q.M. Nicolls. after I had finished learnt that he was not at fault & apologised felt rather small.
Entry.296: Fine day 17 & 18 passed through going to Rihemout went for walk to Meaulte with Rouse. Diary turned up to-night possibility of getting leave. All Batt. officers 6 in all mess together. They play cards practically all day long.
Entry.297:
Cold fine day. Marshall left the Batt & Bhimer 
has
 is adjutant 

97

Major Novic came back from leave.
Entry.298: Felt very lonely today and sick of the whole show. Think I shall try for a chemists’ job when I go on leave to London, rather hard to decide whether should stop & help to reorganise Batt. or look after myself. Wrote to Mum not a very cheering letter I am afraid also to Burke & Claude. received a parcel of tobacco from Mr. Parry.
Entry.299: Cold rained practically all day. Have received a lot of wounded officers parcels & have more sweets & socks than can eat without being sick though shall try. Gramaphone goes all day & is very acceptable.
Entry.300:
Rained heavily in morning, cleared at 10 a.m. Left Fricourt 10.30 am passed through Bicourdel, Meault, Dernacourt

98

and billeted in wet tents at Ribemont. The officers stayed in billet we had before, arrived at 4.30 p.m. met Ross Mearns.
Entry.301: Cold day did nothing men rested. moved Coy from tents to billets in the factory where A Coy was billeted before. Blumer is Adjutant and having a rough time as things are upside down in the orderly Room.
Entry.302: had parade in morning walked with Rouse to Heilly in the afternoon & had hot bath & tea in the tea room, tea served by a Harrison Fisher girl.
Entry.303: Paraded in morning. Fixed up N.C.O. in Company. Major Norrie in charge of Batt. Col gone temporarily to Bgd.
Entry.304:
Major Norrie gone to 27th as O.C. Batt. moved off at 9.0 am for Rainnerville via Heilly, Bonnay, Pont Noyelles, Allonville. Had row with Heath before starting. He very easily gets flustered.

99

arrived at destination 5.15 p.m. men very done up. stuck it out very well indeed. E.S.M. doing much better of the talking to he got this morning. Nicolls goes on leave to-morrow. I am down for
Entry.305: I am billeted with Rouse in big room 2 old people very hospitable.
Entry.306: Cold foggy heavy hoar frost, every glade of grass & twig had a layer of ice on windward side ¼" thick. Riffle inspection 2 p.m. Marshall back again. Every frozen solid by 7 p.m.
Entry.307: Frost remained on trees all day. review of General Tegge in afternoon. H & D Coy were best on parade.
Entry.308:
Church parade in the morning. Had to start the Hymns went to Flesselles in afternoon. Frost was falling of trees looked like snow on the road. Had an enjoyable ride though cold. Lecture was on officers & their duties, not bad lecture though delivery not too good.

100
Entry.309:
Sadler 
goes
