 went on leave. Niven to go & then myself. Sat on a Court of enquiry as President today. Weeden returned yesterday & raised the question of seniority. Decided that I am senior. Des Wallach also is back.
Entry.310: Very cold all day. Sat on board in morning. Settled 18 men who were reported missing. 15 killed & 3 cleared to Hosp. Still 55 missing commenced drill in the afternoon.
Entry.311: Sleet most of the day. Cold wind, did musketry inst. & rifle exercises all day. Batt parade for inspection of French general who was a Helles Girand but did not turn up. Wrote to all dead men relations & letter from comfort. Have received last few days 5 letters from home.
Entry.312:
Held G.O.C. parade between here & Cardonette. Insp By Holmes commended 19th for work done in last attack.

101
Entry.313: Asked Colonel about my leave to England. Refused on account of shortage. Only other remark he passed was that his turn ought to be coming round again shortly. parades all day very wet & cold.
Entry.314:
Have bad cold today don’t feel too well. Colonel asked me to give a lecture on the attack. 
on Sunday the 10th
. wrote home 3 good letters to Mum Dad & Marjorie.

Cold went day started lecture at 6.30 p.m. All other officers present was very nervous felt as if a few of them were hostile and it rather upset me. Spoke rather jerkily. However finished up better and it opened up discussion.
Entry.315:
Went into Amiens with Rouse at 10 a.m. on bicycles. Had a look around. Had dinner at the Hotel de Commerce.

102

Then went and had good warm bath. Got our photos taken and then paid a visit to the Cathedral. A mass was taking place at the time and the surroundings of the Altar and the dress of the priests etc. was the grandest I have ever seen. There is no doubt that the R.C. method of teaching religion does appeal to the imagination of the people and I should say that the effect would be more lasting than in our own churches. Had tea & arrived 
home
 in billets about 10 p.m. on way out heard some bombs dropped in Amiens.
Entry.316:
Another cold day. drilled all day. Saw I. Marshall’s room. Weedon, Heath & himself afraid another clique will form as last one did a lot of harm. Scott is a new man

103

He returned yesterday & has been granted D.S.O.
Entry.317:
Carried out an attack on similar lines to the one at Ribemont direction lost a bit as flags were on the slant.
 Heavy fall of snow early this morning made country look very pretty though slushy to walk on.
Entry.318: Carried out an attack on similar lines to the one at Ribemont direction was however lost owing to flags being a bit askant. New officers came out to-day Sill, Jones P.D. C.S.M. Jones, Monro Lipscombe.
Entry.319: Attack as yesterday again carried out, no loss of direction and on whole better done, wrote to Min. Elliot & Dorothy. Sent home cards of Rainmeville & Heilly. Jones P.O. reported to be taken on Coy. strength.
Entry.320:
Cold wet day. Rode to Flesselles with Blumer, Scott 

104

and to a lecture.
Entry.321: Left early in the morning 8.0 a.m. for Franvillers about 6 mls. Had a good billet & stayed the night.
Entry.322: Left Franvillers at 9.0 a.m. & marked to Dermacourt billet occupied by 47th Batt had to wait until 7.30 before could take over.
Entry.323: Stayed here to-day misty but did not rain received 40 reinforcements & officer Allan to D. Coy. Had an inspection by Legge move to Fricourt tomorrow.
Entry.324:
Left Derracourt to visit front line at 7.0 a.m. Horses did not arrive till 8.30 went via Fricourt, Mametz 
and
 Montauban Bemafay wood Delville wood and then to front line. From Delville wood to front line some 2500 yds duck boards over open all way. A few shells fell very close one within 10 yds. After getting details from B.H.Q. in Rose trench returned.

105

cannot go to front line in day time no saps all relief done over open. returned to Bemafay commenced to snow heavily. Roads were very slippery and had practically to hold horses up. Rejoined Batt. at Fricourt after a very cold ride.
Entry.325: Left Fricourt at noon and marked to Montauban roads frozen made good going. Major Beyers gave lecture to newly made officers put more men up for promotion.
Entry.326:
Left Montauban 1.30 p.m. moved to switch trench 
just on
 near Delville wood trench duck boarded & with sufficient dug-outs holding 4 men each to make men comfortable. Spend night in drying shed.
Entry.327:
Rained in the morning finished duck-boarding trench moved to german dug-out much warmer & more room. Had trouble in getting up rations large tank just in front of Delville wood. few shells flying about sent out ration party 8.30 p.m. returned 2.30 a.m.

106
Entry.328: Cold and windy. A company had 6 killed 2 wounded. slept well drew gum boots at Delville wd drying shed.
Entry.329: Clear day very cold. Sadler returned from leave. Moved up to support line Rose trench 5.0 o’clock rations dumped at needle dump. Coy took over at 7.30 p.m. sent 40 men back for ration. Heavy shelling parties mixed up, sorted them out & got them away by 11.0 p.m. Sent Jones to dig-out saps that had been blown in. Had very rough time no casualities. One ration party to C. Coy lost had to find guides & send it out again, returned at 6 a.m.
Entry.330:
Xmas day awakened at 10.0 am. heavy firing by both sides. Had breakfast, bread butter bacon jam & hot tea. One casuality last night in 19th 20th had several some very nasty wounds which I had to dress. One man had all fingers of right hand shot away. went round trench with colonel to see what improvements could be done.

107

dinner some cold meat bread butter jam & hot tea. Same for Tea, wrote letters home.
Entry.331: Find day met an officer in the 28th had not seen since moved up and relieved Heath by 8.0 p.m. very cold night standing over knees in mud. Have a small shelter made of a waterproof sheet which keep off the rain.
Entry.332:
Fine day bright sunshine fairly good ration still very cold, cannot move along trench as get sniped. relieved by 18th Batt. at 8 p.m. made a lot of row & Fritz opened with m. guns. did not get anyone however. It seems wonderful how a relief can be carried out over the open with Fritz only 100 yds away. After relief made way back to switch trench all in by 1 a.m.

28//12/16

Stayed switch all day until relieved by
Entry.333:
Batt. at 5.30 p.m. very cold everything frozen made way to E camp. Bermafay wood arrived there by 7.0 p.m.

108
Entry.334: Cold day Capt Beyrs asked me if I would take on the position of Adjutant as it required at the present time some one with tact to get the Batt going properly. I thought it rather a compliment. I am agreeable not yet fixed up.
Entry.335: Adjutants job did not come off. Wallach is rather weak as yet and he took it over. wet day rather sick laid in bed most of the day went to Y.M.C.A. and have chat with manager, the man behind the counter was Rimington a man I had sent as pack guard to Marseilles from Boeseghem.
Entry.336: Cold and went feel slightly better received letters from Mim and Alice & parcels from Miss Elliot & Mrs. Parry & Home & Alice. Contents came in very useful as we moved to Delville wd. at 4.45 p.m. Saw Chaffie and had a long talk.
Entry.337:
There are 4 in our dug-out and are comfortable.

109

Have plenty to eat some shells flying about.
Entry.338: dull though not raining. Rouse and Trumer with 100 men went out to dig new trench in front of right sector of centre company. Rouse wounded in left breast & arm with bullets should not be serious. Rec. 8 home letters.
Entry.339: Saw Rouse at 8 a.m. did not seem bad gave him a drink and arranged about his gear. Left Delville and went to switch trench relieved 17th Batt. occupied one of small dug-out fairly comfortable
Entry.340: Raining and very raw, stopped in dug-out practically all day. Allan went out at night with party to carry to left Coy. work not all done fine moonlight night.
Entry.341:
Moved up into front line as right coy., took over from D of 20th. O.C. drunk dispositions 3 detached posts no CT’s Coy H.Q. behind centre. 

110

visited posts after relief trenches fairly dug, cover for all men.
Entry.342: Lay low all day, visited posts when it became dark, men in good spirits. Set them work to do intermittent shelling all day no damage, beautiful night froze hard.
Entry.343: Clear day, aircraft very active, visited posts again. Took round Gritten and 7th Bge. intelligence officer, very sloppy trip but otherwise alright. Coming back up sap was caught with 4.2" H.E. some fell very close but none got into trench.
Entry.344: Fair amt of shelling all day at night Fritz threw bombs on sap leading to our bombing post. Relieved at 10 p.m by 27th Batt. very rowdy lot & bad relievers. Went to switch trench without casualities.
Entry.345:
Spent day in switch trench moved at night to Delville wood. men very tired & have sore feet.

111
Entry.346: Left here at 3.30 p.m. for E. camp, just on leaving plane came over very low & had good look around. He got away safely Wood was heavily shelled at night, several casualites among 25th Batt who relieved us.
Entry.347: Cold snowed all day Allan went out on fatigue at 4.45 am. returned at 9 a.m. out again at 5.30 p.m. Jones sick.
Entry.348: Had an easy time in hut, men doing plenty of fatigue work.
Entry.349: Cold day opened lot of dead & wounded mens’ parcels, distributed contents among the platoon. Came in very handy as rations were short. Promotion went on again.
Entry.350: Helped Wallach with work as much as possible. Colonel evacuated to rest camp
Entry.351:
Moved to Danacourt, took train from Quarry siding 12.30 p.m. to Meaulte, marched to Billets. Coy has good billet.

112

beds, tables & chairs & above all a workable stove.
Entry.352: dull but fine, spent day in inspecting billets and getting men to clean up gear for musketry school.
Entry.353: Last night heavy fall of snow fully 6" covered ground completely a beautiful sight to those who have not seen much of it before. At night had A & B Coys officers down & spent a very agreeable night in singing songs and the phonograph, which is a new one bought today.
Entry.354:
Snow still lying heavily on ground, walked to Meaulte with Jones & bought some new records, worked with a sapphire point, some fine records. Allan went with 30 men to musketry school at Pont Remy.

Drs. Wallach, Trim & Sadler came round last night.

114

met Roydhouse again. Some swelled head.

bitterly cold walking back from Alfencourt. Asked lecturer Col Frulkes of gas corps whether any vacancies & he said to put in an application for a transfer. dont know whether will or not.
Entry.355: Another clear day selected ground for inspection of Division G.O.C. tomorrow will be cold if like to day. planes over again. artillery still active.
Entry.356: Spent whole morning in preparing for G.O.C. inspection cold wind blowing. inspection went of fine. transport a picture went to Heilly Tea room some class believe me.
Entry.357: Kit inspection, men very well equipped. Jones acted as barrage for a Bge attack. 17 & 20th attacking 18 support 19 Review done both in morning & afternoon. Batt. looked on for afternoon stunt done very well indeed.
Entry.358:
Still clear frosty weather. Has been below zero now for 10 whole 

115

days appointed as president on Bd. of enquiry about loss of 800 Fr. from Canteen on the 26/1/17, skiding on ice most of day.
Entry.359:
Left for Albert, cold but very clear, good billet went for a walk with Allan. River Ancre frozen over walked across, could see water running underneath. Today is 
Allans
 Jones’ birthday.
Entry.360:
Spent 
day
 morning in billets in the afternoon rode to Martinpuich and then walked to trenches occupied by support Batt. Small dugouts similar to Switch, good walking a bit slippery, everything frozen solid.
Entry.361: Batt left Albert 8.30 am marched to Baryentin (Cinque Ports Camp) via Fricourt & Contalmaison. Camp proved to be an ideal one, every convenience our huts really luxurious.
Entry.362:
Left Cinque Ports Camp at 3.30 p.m. moved to Prue trench in support 

116

Batt system. Have small shelter as Coy H.Q. very cold at night.
Entry.363: Cannot move about much at day-light promotion back again whole coy. out carrying rations to 2 front Batt’s. Some shells fell very close, manage to keep a fire going most of the day & night.
Entry.364: Went to Pioneer camp to court martial, beautiful day, thoroughly enjoyed walk fine moonlight night coming back. Saw Chappie at Contalmaison.
Entry.365: Put in another cold day, coy. out carrying rations again. No shells stop in bed until 10.00 am.
Entry.366:
Spent day in cleaning trenches still frozen hard, relieved by 22nd Batt. at 7.0 
am
 pm moved to shelter wds, aeroplane dropped 2 bombs just missed Coy. killed 4 & wd. 11 of 20th Batt. Have hut bet C & D Coys.
Entry.367:
Spent day in getting clean extremely cold in hut & very draughty, boots socks & clothing frozen stiff every morning, last few days has been 10-15 degrees below zero centigrade. Went all over Poiziers with Jones place not much changed. Saw Heritages grave. main rd. now in good order, full of 8 & 9 Howitzers.

117
Entry.368: Had Kit inspection in morning route march in afternoon, paid men. Too cold to sleep very well. Heavy artillery fire all night.
Entry.369: Visited sector to be taken over by the Batt. Series of detached posts north of Bapaime Rd on left of Le Sars. Arrived back at camp 2.30 a.m. Jones & Allan had a meal ready for me.
Entry.370: Had sleep, left Shelter Wood 3.30 p.m. picked up guide to each post at Bge 5 p.m. moved to frontline, relief complete by 8.30 p.m, no casualities. Sniping pretty good. Had to take guides back to Batt. H.Q. to show them the way, caught in Le Sars wd with shells, no one hit.
Entry.371:
Remained in doors all day, visited posts at night, men comfortable though bit cold, drink question rather a problem as all in bottles are frozen and not enough cookers to thaw them out. Stunt at night, raids by 4 & 5 Batt on our right successful.

118

Lieut. Kirkwood camp up to have look round, will relieve me to-morrow night. Visit by Major Beiers.
Entry.372: Quiet relieved late at night, proceeded to 26th Avenue as reserve. Sadler returned from raiders, settled in new position by 2.30 a.m.
Entry.373: Slept most of day, supplied ration parties at night, fairly comfortable tin dug-out.
Entry.374: Another quiet day eating & sleeping. Went up to camp where raiding party were practicing and saw Jones who is Training them, work very well, seem quite enthusiastic.
Entry.375:
Day warm real pleasant to be about. Thaw has set in properly will probably rain shortly. Saw another raid practice throwing live bombs.

119
Entry.376: Spent day on a court martial, did three men, also had 2 boards of inquiry. Anderson returned to Batt. looks very well & fit.
Entry.377: Cleaned up camp ready to move, moved to Shelter wood camp at 4.30 p.m. heavy fog, thought had lost my valise turned up after a time, thank goodness.
Entry.378: Raiders left to day for Bairyieux for further training accompanied by James and Sadler. weather warm and wet will be wet now I suppose till summer. made Capt.
Entry.379:
Rifle inspection. Visited sector of line to be taken over. left camp with Foster of “C" Coy at 2.30 & Major Beiers relieving C. Norrie 25th again. Visited posts in front line. Had to wait until 1.30 a.m. for Foster to return, arrived back 3.30 
p.m.
 am. Mayor Beiers had narrow escape coming home from shell. Scott arrived back.
Entry.380: Slept until midday. Had brolga at night to celebrate captaincy dated from 12/1/17, also a lot of 2nd stars through Allan of 17th stayed all night, wet day.
Entry.381: wet day, moved up & relieved 28th in Prue trench & owing to accident to Mgr Beiers arrived Prue trench 10.0 p.m. very slow trip owing to darkness.
Entry.382: practically no shelling here now, supplied ration parties. New officer Hall joined us at Shelter wood.
Entry.383:
supplied ration parties again, wet & cold.

24/2/17

Reported that Bosh has evacuated Butter 1st &
Entry.384: went over to find out how things were, proved to be correct.
Entry.385:
Took coy out as carrying party formed new dump on Bapaume nearly opposite Butter. arrived back at 2.0 am, no casualities though heavy shelling. moved up to 

121

Le sars cutting, other Battalions moved forward in front of Butter. When arrived at cutting was informed by Col. Ralston that I had to proceed to Galluity trench the original German front line. I did this & took up my position at 4.00 p.m., company carried S.A.A. & bombs forward until day break.

26/2/17

Fine day, trench not in good 
position
 condition, 18th Batt & 20th moved forward at 1.30 p.m. towards Le Barge and Thilloy, got well forward until help up by m. guns, and took up a general line in an old watercourse.
Entry.386: During last night these 2 Batt, dug in as well as possible. At 1.0 a.m. received orders to relieve the
Entry.387:
Batt. in the watercourse – Thames – did so and just got in by day break without casualities though 

122

enemy m gun fire from Le Barge very severe.
Entry.388:
In morning A & B Coys made a bombing attack on that part of Malt trench in front of them. The attack was partly a success gaining about 300 yds of trench. But through some mistake they withdrew so that attack had to be made again. This time 
had
 gained same amount of ground though had several killed through m. gun fire, the trench was in an awful condition and it is a wonder any advance was made at all. We held this ground during the night, was put in charge of front line.
Entry.389:
A stokes mortar was put in position last night so made up my mind to use it. The front 
was
 held so strongly by Fritz was the junction of the front line trench and a C.T. turning back 
this
 the Grevillers line

1/3/17

a well.

consolidated line about 800 yds behind Malt trench. I got the trench mortar to fire 50 rounds on this point, and then advanced 2 bombing squads. After a lot of bombing succeeded in gaining this front. The barrage put up during over attack was the worst I had seen since Pozieres. Yesterday had the narrowest escape ever. When going to bring up D coy to reinforce A & B, I was hit on the arm by a 4.2 shell, it burnt the arm, slewed me round & pushed me into a shell hole. The only mark is a burnt sleeve and a cut about ¼" deep. The shell burst about 20 yds in front of me.
Entry.390:
Brigade has evidently come to the same mind as myself as today they turned on the C.o. fr. bomb.

124

2/3/17

and the Heavies. The retaliation was very severe. The Batt. has lost about 60 men. D. Coy 3 killed 18 wd. Were relieved to-night by the 17th Batt. & moved out along Bapaume Rd. to Martinpuich Valley to Cinque Ports camp. Had a feed and played gramaphone. Slept today from 4 a.m. to 4 p.m.
Entry.391: Moved to Scots Redoubt South, good hut, had good sleep. Potts our new cook doing splendidly.
Entry.392: Left camp at 10.0 a.m. with Kirkwood, Allan and Foster on Horses to ride to Heilly. Had most enjoyable ride. Had hot bath and then dinner, Omellettes 2, port beans & roast potatoes, cheese & biscuits, wine & coffee. Had walk round village & then after some Tea & cake rode back via Albert.
Entry.393: Practiced attack on a wood, Mametz, looks like a loop over, did 2 practices.
Entry.394: Rec. orders to move to Bagentin le Grand. Left camp at 12.30 p.m. and moved to new camp, arrived there 2.30 p.m. went forward with Major Beires to reserve position, returned at 8.0 p.m.
Entry.395: Cold day. Sent Robinson forward to Yarra reserve to take over Coy. left Bagentin at 8.45 p.m. arrived at Yarra & found that had to go to Cobbam trench, another 1000 yds further on. got there & relieved Egerby, brother of Jack Egerby of S & S.
Entry.396: Snowed, went for walk to get my bearings, we are in front of Eaucourt L’Abbay & on right of Butter. Coy in 2 large dug-outs.
Entry.397:
Went to H.Q. Trennery evacuated with mumps & Major Beires has them. 5 officers to go to a new in 6th Division. Those going are Robinson, , Townsen, Charcour &

Swinbourne. Sell is to go to 5th T.B. England, very glad he is going. Allan went out on carrying party.
Entry.398: Feeling very well, not much exercise. Major Beiers evac. last night, Scott temp. in command fatigue party at night.
Entry.399: Should have moved up to-night, movement cancelled, very fine day, our artillery heavily bombarded Grevillers line all day.
Entry.400: Another fine day. rec. orders to move across to 26th Av. & relieved Coy in 26th av. by 12.0 mid-night. reconnoitred ground myself during day & then brought coy across very tired rained during night & had to work to keep rain out. Saw Bill Lome 5th Bge artillery.
Entry.401: Beautiful day. weather another heavy bombardment of Grevillers line, moved up to Le Sars cutting relieved 17th Batt. who went to front line.
Entry.402:
Just settled down by 1.0 a.m. & just got to sleep when rec. orders

127

that Hun had again retired & to pack up. moved up to sunken Rd on left of Marlencourt by 5.0 a.m. spent day in building homes & at 8.0 p.m. moved again to Loupait Rd. where made H.Q. in dug-out.
Entry.403: Slept well, very tired awakened at 11.0 a.m. & had breakfast. Visited men & village, saw on Bapaume Rd. above Le Sars camp of bell tents asking for trouble they got it, heavily shelled.
Entry.404:
went & visited front line lost coming home spent several hours roaming round, picked up ration party brought party home.

16/3/17

camp moved. Hall left for a school spent very quiet day.
Entry.405: moved up & relieved 17th Batt. D Coy. good deal of m. gun fire, supposed to be a stunt by 18th Batt. did not come off. splendid patrol work done during night by Marshall McDonald & Williams, enemy reported to be very active during night in his front line.
Entry.406:
Talking heard up to 5.30 a.m. at about 6.0 a.m. the Hun evacuated

128

my company was first to report evac. & to move on a 30 ml front. Had Allan standing by with 30 men. as soon as he rec. word from me he moved forward cut the wire in 2 places & made 2 entries into german line opposite village of Grevillers. a few minutes afterward & company moved forward and cleared village. I them moved up the rest of D coy into trenches & sent 2 platoons forward again to support left of C coy which was being held up with m. gun fire. A good deal of Hun sniping was going on D coy lost 1 killed 1 wounded. when village was cleared, recalled coy into railway cutting ad place L.G. on left flank. Saw a fight bet. Hun & a british patrol Hun got away. that night counted 10 fires all round the horizon Hun was burning the villages as he retired, absolutely nothing was left behind. Bapaume was burning fiercely.
Entry.407:
A spring day. 6 Bge took over whole front and cavalry pushed through.

192
Entry.408: Rec. orders at 3 a.m. to move. these orders were however cancelled and spent day in roaming round. Horses are coming up shall go for a ride.
Entry.409: Felt very sick, ate nothing lay on floor of hut all day.
Entry.410: A little better today, rode into Bargentin to get some clean clothes from valise. snowed heavily on return journey.
Entry.411:
Washed those had on 
and
 in turn doing one at a time.
Entry.412:
men have built very fine shelters in cutting, looks quite like a village, tents and artillery are all over place.

25/3/17

Went for walk to Bapaume saw Potts in 4th Divi. Engineers demolishing houses, place very much knocked about. Shells arrive in town occasionally.

26/3/17

Lt. Robinson went to Bepaume for a walk to have look round rec. orders at 11.30 a.m. to be ready to move. Very crook again.

130

finally did not move that day.

27/3/17

moved this morning at 1.30 a.m. very dark & cold went to Beugnatre via Favrevile, arrived there at 4.30 a.m. The 7th Bge. Tommies & 5th Division attack at 5.15 a.m. at 5 a.m. called to
Entry.413: Bg & told to move to a trench between Beugnatre & Vrancourt. arrived at 6.30 a.m. raining hard & very cold. put in 4 or 5 very miserable hours & then moved to a sunken Rd east of Vaulx. From there the Coy. Commanders went up to the front line and finally took over from
Entry.414:
Batt. the front line that night. C & D coy front line. Village of Lagnicourt had been captured in the morning but few casualities taking 100 prisoners. front line & series m posts 200 yds in front of village. Put watches forward one hour.

132
Entry.415: Coy H.Q. and village heavily shelled all day, quietened up at night, were relieved by 52nd Batt at 8 p.m. moved to Vaulx-Vrancourt where men had a hot meal and then on to Javreuil where stayed remainder of night in old german huts.
Entry.416: Spent morning looking round village. Saw grave of Capt. Pemberton R.F.C. well kept in german cementry. All dates had been removed. moved from village at 1.30 p.m. and marked to Bayentin-le-Petit via Bapaume. La Cuple Guerile, Le Sars & Martinpuick, arrived there 4 p.m. rejoined by Major Beiers, Hall & Trennery.
Entry.417:
Left Bayentin at 10.0 a.m. & marched to Fricourt camp. we probably remain here some time set to work to made hut comfortable. result very pleasing Hall put up all

132

the pictures of his lady-loves about 100 in all.
Entry.418:
Had inspection and general cleaning up of men. reinforcements coming in every day. 
new officer Lt. Hinds of Mosman Rifle Club joined D Coy today
 presentation of medals by Birdwood. Had guard of honour.
Entry.419: Sunday. Church parade joined by Lt. Hinds of Mosman rifle club. recognised me. Archie Allan & Robinson left yesterday. Robo to England & Archie to Army school. leaves company very short.
Entry.420: Started parades. men look well & clean. do rifle exercises etc very well.
Entry.421:
Very cold day, snowing heavily makes ground very wet to work on. Have to do the best we can as 
ground
 time is limited. Townsen made fool of himself last night at a lecture will be up for Court-martial.

133
Entry.422: Snowed heavily all day, men remained inside, gave them lectures on attack etc. to pass away the time. 2 days ago put in application for the job of 6th Div. gas officer.
Entry.423:
Not feeling too well. Field Officer of the day. Visited all the Batt’s, all men on duty. Gus Morgan is no attached to this Batt as 
an
 the R.M.O.
Entry.424: Rec. orders to relieve 2 Coy of 17th at Le Sars on board making. relieved them by 6.0 p.m. bad trouble with transport road to camp very bad.
Entry.425: Rained part of day, cleared up in afternoon very comfortable 2 of us in tent, Hinds & myself. burning coal off the Le Sars dump.
Entry.426:
wet practically all day, lie in bed until 11.0 a.m. Some stunt

134
Entry.427: Fine day went for a walk with Hinds to village of Pys very much knocked about sim. to Le Sars.
Entry.428: Rec. orders to move back to crucific camp, moved after had finished days work, arrived back at 8 p.m.
Entry.429: Remained in camp all day awaiting orders to move they did not come. Had a good nights sleep which put me right again.
Entry.430: Moved to Favreuil fine day though cold wind. Took all day moving slept in village in part of broken down house very comfortable had large fire burning all night.
Entry.431: moved at 6.30 p.m. to Noreuil took up position in Sunken Rd. men had to dig themselves in for most part. A Coy of 17th Batt in same road.
Entry.432:
Went back to Beugnatre on Court Martial of Townson

135

going on leave seems certain have pass and everything ready. Reported to Bge & was told could not go on leave. I was really disappointed. All arrangements had been made for an attack on the Hindenburg line but were cancelled at mid-night.
Entry.433:
Very little artillery during night at 3.0 a.m. a couple of 12th Batt men came in to say the Germans were right through & advancing on us. We immediately stood too. I rec. orders to take up a position to cover our right flank. I had 2 guns and 1 ft posted when Fritz hit us on the left flank forcing both the platoon & guns to retire. This retirement was caused by some unauthorised person giving the order. if those guns had not retired the Hun would never have reached the sunken road. 

Then I saw that both the guns & the Platoon had come in. I got 2 lewis guns in the road, a third 50 yds to the right & a platoon to the right of the road. 
The
 all of these concentrated their fire on the enemy guns which were enfilading the road and causing me heavy casualities. this fire was successful and the two enemy guns were abandoned by their crews, and afterwards captured by us. Fritz got into bombing range on our right and commenced to throw bombs but 1 
nil
 mills killed three & the bombing ceased, 
Then
 While this was going on I sent a platoon to the left flank & they were successful in stopping the german advance along the L Hirondelle river. 
Fritz
 our own artillery in Noreuil pulled their guns out into the road and fired point blank at the Hun advancing 

over the ridge, the first shots were short and got some of my fellows. I tried & think succeeded in raising him by standing up on the bank and signalling with my arm the battery was not more than 500 yds away. a couple burst short in front of me & I though I was gone. Firstly tried to stop the signalling business from behind. The Hun then started to retire in 2s & 3s seeing this I sent out 5 patrols to hurry matters & the first batch that they brought in was 77. the prisoners altogether numbered 150 & 4 officers. 2 german maxims gun & 2 lewis captured by him some time before. In 2 hours from the start all was quiet. I was recommended but dont know how things have got 
up
 on. Belcher did some fine work.

138
Entry.434: Quiet day, very little shelling rained most of day, very cold don’t know when stunt is coming off.
Entry.435: Went into Favreuil to meeting of 4 Div. officers & talked about the stunt, the failure was mostly due to the tanks & shortage of bombs & S.A.A.
Entry.436: Rained all day & very cold, moved coy. over to sunken road near Lagnicourt at night. A & B Coy. took over front line, we are in support. Had to dig in.
Entry.437: Fine day though very cold. Fritz shelled artillery heavily, got several men though no guns. Relieved by 7th Bge at night, relief complete by 1.30 a.m.
Entry.438:
Moved out to trench between Vaulx & Beugnatre arrived there 4 a.m. Have shelter for 3 of us, valise arrived very comfortable.

139
Entry.439: Rested all day, beautiful fine weather, being well fed looks like the fatening before the Kill.
Entry.440: Another day of rest, fine day, have stand too at 7.30 p.m. & 4.0 a.m. precautions after the last stunt.
Entry.441: Practice for stunt on Hindenburg line, all trenches, roads & wire marked out, great idea, no intention of failing. Stunt went off very well indeed.
Entry.442:
Another practice today, went off better than yesterday. very enjoyable to be out in the air when the weather is nice. Summer seems to have set in.

25/4/17

Still beautiful weather 
another practice today
 another practice today, good to be out in the air walk about 3 mls to the practice ground. Have dinner & then the stunt. 2 Bges out 5th &
Entry.443:
should give Fritz a fight if he sees them coming over. 
during night stunt tonight went into tents on other side of Favreuil
 

140
Entry.444: Rested during day, stunt practice early tomorrow morning. moved into tents on the other side of Favreuil.
Entry.445: Left camp at 12.30 a.m. moved to jumping off line. Barrage marked by L.H. carrying flares. At zero hour this Batt was the only one ready to move, others very late. 17th caught up on German wire, rather spoil show, moved back to tents & then to trench. later on we moved back to the tents will remain here until stunt.
Entry.446: Beautiful day very comfortable in tents, drilled this morning practice stunt in conjunction with 20th Batt. in the afternoon. Rec. parcel from Alice.
Entry.447: Sunday went to church in morning.
Entry.448: Bge band played us home through Favreuil. Band played all the afternoon in camp. Summer weather.
Entry.449:
Did another practice 2 Bges. Zero hour 4 a.m. went off all right, have orders to be ready to move forward

141

it looks like the real thing. Such a beautiful day, did not go to sleep, rec. orders at 10.0 p.m. to move to Noreuil.
Entry.450: Left camp at 12.0 midnight and arrived at Noreuil 3.30 a.m. relieved 7th Bge, very tired, had a sleep remained there all that day, drew bombs etc.
Entry.451: Another fine day went up to have look at Reincourt. a German aeroplane brought down by m.gun fire.
Entry.452: Spent day in getting final instructions and issuing colours, bombs etc. Davies, Avard , Mason and myself lay down for a few hours before we moved off all were in the best of spirits.
Entry.453:
Batt moved off at 12.30 a.m. 
A,B
 B.A. D.C. few shells fell near on way to jumping off tapes.

142

Everything fixed up by 3.30 a.m. Zero hour 3.45 a.m. The barrage started on left towards Bullecourt first and then our own started. The front lines were slow to move, they could be distinctly seen owing to the flashes of the shells. The Hun m.guns and barrage started at the same time. The waves in front of me lost direction and moved too much to the right and the rear lines 20th Batt moved faster than our line, and on the right of the Reincourt had passed right through them. The lines up to the wire were fairly good it was reached at 3.50 a.m. leaves 2 minutes to go before the barrage lifted off O.G.I. this necessitated 

143

a halt when the 2 first waves were in the wire and this halt proved our undoing. The m.gun fire of the hun was terrific and the men who were in groups of 2 and 3’s did not move forward as a whole when the time was up. On the contrary an order seems to have been given by an officer (unknown) to pull out. The result being that the men who were practically without officers or N.C.O.’s retired. I continued and pulled up in a C.T. joining the Hindenburg line with 30 men. There were with me Lt. Hinds and Lt. Kant, who was afterwards killed. We made a block with sand-bags & wire near the Hun mail line & prepared to stay all day.

144

As soon as the Hun found where we were he started to bomb but was beaten off. the men 
were very
 with a few exceptions displayed no spirit at all even when the hun got within a few yards of them they had no intention of fighting, there only thoughts were how to get out. Had at one time made an attempt to show a white flag. We successfully held on all day losing men both from our own and Fritz artillery. At night fall, seeing that the bombing on our left did not advance near enough for us to effect a junction, we decided to withdraw so at 9.30 p.m. under very heavy m.gun fire the wounded were sent under good men out of 

145

to the rear end of the trench. By 10.30 only 6 of us were left 2 of these I sent away and at 11.0 p.m. moved off with the last party. At the end of the trench we found a man with a broken thigh. Sgt Carter of the 17th Batt myself and 2 others started to get him out. The first man to leave the trench got shot in the arm. Carter bandaged him & sent him away. The wounded man was now shoved over the parapet and dragged forwards a few yards by Carter. I next moved out and found that to move him any further he had to be lifted over the back wire, so getting a good hold we tried our luck. 3 m.guns where immediately 

146

on to us and though sparks flew out of the wire in all directions we managed to reach a shell hole a few yards away clear of the wire. From here on with the aid of the other man we managed to 
get
 make progress by means of short stages, shell hole to shell hole until we reached the Reincourt Rd where we were too far away for the m.guns to do accurate shooting. ½ way to the railway cutting we found a stretcher and completed the journey in comfort. I arrived at 
the
 H.Q. at 3.0 a.m. had sleep & then moved to Vaulx where the Batt spent the day. The officers lost men killed Davies, Avard.

147

Mason, Kirkwood, Kant missing Breckenridge and Fitzgerald wounded Blumer, Townson, McMeckin, Foster.
Entry.454: At 12.30 p.m. rec. orders to move to a camp (tented) near Biefvillers. On arrived turned in and slept until dinner time, joined up by Hall, Allan, Neilsen, McDonald.
Entry.455: Cleaned up, took shortages etc. very fine weather.
Entry.456: Commenced drill & at 10 a.m. rec. word to go on leave. Left camp 2.30 p.m. arrived Albert 4.30 p.m. stayed there night in building run under E.F.C. very nice place.
Entry.457:
moved to Boulogne by trained arrived there 11.30 p.m. found bed stayed night.

148
Entry.458: Boarded leave boat 10.0 a.m. had good run across to Folkestone arrived London 3.0 p.m. went to Horseferry Rd and then to Germyn Court Hotel. Have good room bath attached. got trunk from Cook’s and bought new clothes went to Regent’s Palace for tea met Ronald Cook of 17th & then to a show. Had Taxi ride after show.
Entry.459: Rang up Miss Tytherleigh & went out there for tea, very nice people put in good evening singing songs. Spent early part of day in strolling round the town, looking at the people. Girls very pretty, fine complexions 90% of them are on the street.
Entry.460:
Spent good day round town went out to M – 4 General & saw Grace Elliot looks very pretty 

149

younger than when on the boat.
Entry.461: town in the morning to Miss Tythesleigh in afternoon. Visited Golf links for afternoon tea sang songs at night. Miss Hunt was there a very pretty girl sings & plays beautifully.
Entry.462: Went to rotten row in morning. bad horses and riders great crowd of people looking on. Saw Gregg, went with Grace Elliot to her Aunt’s for afternoon tea. showing me to the family sort of thing very nice. Went out to Hunt at night.
Entry.463:
Spent day in visiting Southall for Wilson he was out. Saw Archie Allan’s mother and sister – Mrs. Toohey – went out to 

150

tea with Mrs. Meechan an exceptionally nice woman treated me like a son. Introduced me to a family there. 3 very pretty girls one was very fond of Lr. Avard.
Entry.464: Spent day with Bill Lane went to Australia House to try & get over munition factory. nothing doing. Prof. Bannaclough in charge of the munition workers. Will see him before I leave here. went to Theatre – Adelphin High Jinks with Misses Hunt & Tytherleigh some play. Saw them home, lost last tube arrived back 2 a.m.
Entry.465:
Went out on river with Grace Elliot, all day arrived back at 10.p.m. river beautiful one continuous beautiful picture the best piece

152

of artificial scenery I have ever seen. Took some photos but light not too good.
Entry.466: Out with Bill Lowe all day, went to Zoo at Regents Park. Saw Little bit Fluff at Criterion.
Entry.467: Had dinner & saw a show with Major Boase Hanky Panky & then took Min Elliot to Wanted a Husband at the Playhouse at night.
Entry.468: Leave ended today should have gone to France will do so tomorrow morning. It has been one continual rush very little sleep but to sleep here seems waste of time. What struck me most was the suburbs. There each house has only a small amount of ground but it is kept so well, everything looks so neat & clean.
